publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Liſauro, Terzo, Iſmena, and Aminta.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: _LEt the Coach go round, wee'l walk along theſe Meadows:
And meet at Port again: Come my fair Siſter,
Theſe cool ſhades will delight ye.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Pray be merry,
The Birds ſing as they meant to entertain ye,
Every thing ſmiles abroad: me thinks the River
(As he ſteals by) curles up his head, to view ye:
Every thing is in Love.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: You would have it ſo.
You that are fair, are eaſie of belief, Coſen,
The Theame ſlides from your Tongue.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I fair, I thank ye:
Mine's but ſhadow when your Sun ſhines by me.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: No more of this, you know your worth (Aminta)
Where are we now?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hard by the Town (Iſmena)

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Cloſe by the Gates:

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: 'Tis a fine Ayre.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: A delicate;
The way ſo ſweet and even, that the Coach
Would be a tumbling trouble to our pleaſures,
Methinks I am very merry:

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I am ſad:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You are ever ſo when we entreat ye (Coſen)

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I have no reaſon: ſuch a trembling here
Over my heart methinks:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sure you are faſting,
Or not ſlept well to night; ſome dream (Iſmena)

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: My dreams are like my thoughts, honeſt, and innocent,
Yours are unhappy; who are theſe that coaſt us? Enter Antonio & Martin.
You told me the walk was private.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt commonly:

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Two proper men: it ſeems they have ſome buſines,
With me none ſure; I do not like their faces;
They are not of our Company:

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: No Coſen:
Liſauro, we are dog'd.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I find it (Coſen)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What handſome Lady?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, ſhee's very handſom.
They are handſome both,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Martin, ſtay we are coſened.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will go up; a woman is no wild-fire.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now by my life ſhe is ſweet: Stay good Martin,
They are of our enemies; the Houſe of Belides,
Our mortal enemies:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let 'em be devills,
They appear ſo handſomly, I will go forward;
If theſe be enemies, I'le ne'er ſeek friends more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prethee forbear; the Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's it (man)
That mopes me like a Gin.
'Pray ye ſtand off Ladies:

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: They are both our enemies: both hate us equally;
By this fair day our mortal foes.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I know'em,
And come here to affront: how they gape at us?
They ſhall have gaping-work.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Why your ſwords, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Pray ye ſtand you off, Coſen,
And good now leave your whiſtling: we are abus'd all,
Back, back I ſay:

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Go back.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We are no doggs Sir,
To run back on command.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Wee'l make ye run, Sir,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Having a civil charge of handſom Ladies,
We are your ſervants: pray ye no quarrel Gentlemen.
There's way enough for both.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Wee'l make it wider.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If you will fight arm'd, from this Saint; have at ye.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: O me unhappy, are ye Gentlemen?
Diſcreet, and Civil, and in open view thus?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What will men think of us? nay you may kill us;
Mercy o'me: through my petticoat; what bloody gentlemē!

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Make way through me, ye had beſt, and kill an innocent:
Brother, why Coſen: by this light Ile die too:
This Gentleman is temperate: be you merciful:
Alas, the Swords.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You had beſt run me through the belly,
'Twill be a valiant thruſt.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I faint amongſt ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pray ye be not fearful; I have done (ſweet Lady)
My ſword's already aw'd, and ſhall obey ye:
I come not here to violate ſweet beauty,
I bow to that.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Brother, you ſee this Gentleman,
This Noble Gentleman,

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Let him avoid then,
And leave our Walk.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The Lady may command Sir,
She bears an eye more dreadful then your weapon.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: What a ſweet nature this man has? dear brother,
Put up your ſword.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Let them put up and walk then:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more loud words: there's time enough before us:
For ſhame put up, do honour to theſe beauties:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Our way is this,
We will not be denyde it.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: And ours is this, we will not be croſs'd in it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What ere your way is (Lady) 'tis a fair one;
And may it never meet with rude hands more,
Nor rough uncivil Tongues. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I thank ye Sir,
Indeed I thank ye nobly: A brave Enemie,
Here's a ſweet temper now: This is a man (Brother)
This Gentleman's anger is ſo nobly ſeated,
That it becomes him: Yours proclaim ye Monſters.
What if he be our Houſe-Foe? we may brag on't:
We have ne'er a friend in all our Houſe ſo honourable:
I had rather from an Enemie, my Brother,
Learn worthy diſtances and modeſt difference.
Then from a race of empty friends, loud nothings:
I am hurt between ye.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: So am I, I fear too:
I am ſure their ſwords were between my leggs; deer Coſen
Why look ye pale? where are ye hurt?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I know not,
But here me-thinks.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Unlace her gentle Coſen.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: My heart, my heart, and yet I bleſſe the Hurter.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Is it ſo dangerous?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I faint not.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Here is no blood that I find, ſure 'tis inward:

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Yes, yes, 'tis inward: 'twas a ſubtle weapon,
The hurt not to be cur'd I fear.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: The Coach there.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: May be affright.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Aminta, 'twas a ſweet one,
And yet a cruel.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Now I find the wound plain:
A wondrous handſome Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Oh no deeper:
Prethee be ſilent (wench) it may be thy cauſe.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You muſt be ſearched: the wound will rancle; Coſen
And of ſo ſweet a nature.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Deer Aminta:
Make it not ſorer.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: And on my life admires ye.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Call the Coach, Coſen.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: The Coach, the Coach.

sp.speaker: Ter,
sp.l: 'Tis ready, bring the Coach there.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Well my brave enemies, we ſhall yet meet ye,
And our old hate ſhall teſtifie.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: It ſhall (Coſen.) Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Their ſwords, alas, I weigh'em not (deer Friend)
The indiſcretion of the Owners blunts'em;
The fury of the Houſe affrights not me,
It ſpends it ſelf in words: (Oh me Martine)
There was a two edg'd eye, a Lady carried
A weapon that no valour can avoyd,
Nor Art (the hand of Spirit) put aſide.
O Friend, it broke out on me like a bullet
Wrapt in a cloud of fire: that point (Martine)
Dazled my ſence, and was too ſubtle for me,
Shot like a Comet in my face, and wounded
(To my eternal ruine) my hearts valour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Methinks ſhe was no ſuch peece.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Blaſpheme not Sir,
She is ſo far beyond weak commendation,
That impudence will bluſh to think ill of her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I ſee it not, and yet I have both eies open:
And I could judge, I know there is no beauty
Till our eies give it'em, and make'em hanſom;
What's red and white, unles we do allow'em?
A green face elſe; and me-thinks ſuch an other.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace thou leud Heretick; Thou judge of beauties?
Thou haſt an excellent ſenſe for a ſigne-poſt (Friend)
Doſt thou not ſee? Ile ſwear thou art ſoon blind elſe,
As blind as ignorance; when ſhe appear'd firſt
Aurora breaking in the eaſt, and through her face,
As if the Hours and Graces had ſtrew'd Roſes,
A bluſh of wonder flying; when ſhe was frighted
At our uncivil ſwords, didſt thou not mark
How far beyond the purity of ſnow
The ſoft wind drives whitenes of innocence,
Or any thing that bears Celeſtial palenes,
She appear'd o'th'ſodain? Didſt thou ſee her tears
When ſhe intreated? O thou Reprobate!
Didſt thou not ſee thoſe orient tears flow'd from her,
The little Worlds of Love? A ſett (Martine)
Of ſuch ſanctified Beads, and a holy heart to love
I could live ever a Religious Hermite.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do beleeve a little, and yet me-thinks
She was of the loweſt ſtature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A rich Diamond
Set neat and deep; Natures chief Art (Martine)
Is to reſerve her Modells curious,
Not cumberſome and great; and ſuch a one
For fear ſhe ſhould exceed, upon her matter
Has ſhe fram'd this; Oh 'tis a ſpark of beauty,
And where they appear ſo excellent in little,
They will but flame in great; Extention ſpoils'em:
Martine learn this, the narrower that our eies
Keep way unto our object, ſtill the ſweeter
That comes unto us: Great bodies are like Countries,
Diſcovering ſtill, toyle and no pleaſure finds'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A rare Coſmographer for a ſmall Iſland.
Now I believe ſhe is handſom.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Belive heartily,
Let thy belief, though long a coming, ſave thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She was (certain) fair.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But heark ye (Friend Martine)
Do not believe your ſelf too far before me,
For then you may wrong me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who bid ye teach me?
Do you ſhow me meat, and ſtitch my lips (Antonio?)
Is that fair play?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now if thou ſhouldſt abuſe me,
And yet I know thee for an arrant Wencher,
A moſt immoderate thing; thou canſt not love long.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A little ſerves my turn, I fly at all games,
But I believe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How if we never ſee her more?
Shee is our enemie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why are you jealous then?
As far as I conceive ſhe hates our whole Houſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yet (good Martine)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, come, I have mercy on ye:
You ſhall enjoy her in your dream (Antonio)
And I'll not hinder: though now I perſwade my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sit with perſwaſion down, and you deal honeſtly:
I will look better on her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay, who's this, Friend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is't not the other Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, a Letter.
She brings no challenge ſure: if ſhe do (Antonio)
I hope ſhee'l be a Second too; I am for her.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A good houre Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are welcom Lady;
'Tis like our late rude paſſage has powr'd on us
Some reprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: No, I bring no anger,
Though ſome deſerv'd it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sure we were all too blame, Lady;
But for my part (in all humility
And with no little ſhame) I ask your pardons,
Indeed I wear no ſword to fright ſweet beauties.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You have it, and this Letter; pray ye Sir view it,
And my Commiſſion's done.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have ye none for me Lady?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Not at this time.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am ſorry for't; I can read too.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I am glad: but Sir, to keep you in your exerciſe,
You may chance meet with one ill written.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thank ye,
So it be a womans, I can pick the meaning,
For likely they have but one end.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You ſay true Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Martine, my wiſhes are come home and loaden,
Loaden with brave return: moſt happy, happy:
I am a bleſſed man: where's the Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Gone, the ſpirit's gone: what news?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis from the Lady;
From her we ſaw: from that ſame miracle,
I know her Name now: read but theſe three lines;
Read with devotion, friend, the lines are holy.

sp.speaker: Martine
sp.l: I dare not chide ye in my Letter (Sir)
'Twill be too gentle: If you pleaſe to look me
In the Weſt-ſtreet, and find a fair Stone window,
Carved with white Cupids; there Ile entert ain ye:
Night and diſcretion guide ye.
Call me Iſmena.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give it me again: Come, come, fly, fly, I am all fire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There may be danger.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So there is to drink
When men are thirſty, to eat haſtily
When we are hungry: ſo there is in ſleep, Friend,
Obſtructions then may riſe, and ſmother us,
We may die laughing, choked, even at devotions:
An Apoplexie, or a ſodain Palſey
May ſtrike us down.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: May be a train to catch ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then I am caught: and let Love anſwer for it.
'Tis not my ſolly, but his infamy:
And if he be adored, and dare do vild things.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well, I will go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She is a Lady, Sir,
A Maid, I think, and where that holy ſpell
Is flung about me, I ne're fear a villany,
'Tis almoſt night: away friend.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am ready,
I think I know the houſe too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then we are happy. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Did you meet him?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: And did you give my Letter?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: To what end went I?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Are ye ſure it was he?
Was it that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Do you think I was blind?
I went to ſeek no Carrier, nor no Midwife.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: What kind of man was he? thou maiſt be decei|ved Friend.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A man with a noſe on's face: I think he had eies too,
And hands: for ſure he took it.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: What an anſwer?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What queſtions are theſe to one that's hot and troubled?
Do you think me a Babe? am I not able (Coſen)
At my years and diſcretion, to deliver
A Letter handſomly! is that ſuch a hard thing?
Why every wafer-woman will undertake it:
A Sempſters girle, or a Taylors wife will not miſſe it:
A Puritane Hoſteſſe (Coſen) would ſcorn theſe queſtions.
My legges are weary.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I'll make'em well again.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Are they at Supper?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Yes, and I am not well,
Nor deſire no company: look out, 'tis darkiſh.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I ſee nothing yet: aſſure your ſelf, Iſmena,
If he be a man he will not miſſe.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: It may be he is modeſt,
And that may pull him back from ſeeing me;
Or has made ſome wild conſtruction of my eaſineſſe:
I bluſh to think what I writ.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What ſhould ye bluſh at?
Bluſh when you act your thoughts, not when you write 'em;
Bluſh ſoft between a pair of ſheets, ſweet Coſen,
Though he be a curious carried Gentleman, I cannot think
He's ſo unnatural to leave a woman,
A young, a noble, and a beauteous woman,
Leave her in her deſires: Men of this age
Are rather prone to come before they are ſent for.
Hark, I hear ſomthing: up to th'Chamber, Coſen,
You may ſpoil all elſe.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Let me ſee, they are Gentlemen;
It may be they.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: They are they: get ye up,
And like a Land-ſtar draw him.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I am ſhamefac'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am looking for the houſe:
Cloſe, cloſe, pray ye cloſe here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, this is a Merchants;
I know the man well:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And this a Pothecaries: I have lain here many times.
For a looſenes in my Hilts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Have ye not paſt it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No ſure:
There is no houſe of mark that we have ſcaped yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What place is this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Speak ſofter: 'may be ſpies;
If any, this, a goodly window too,
Garv'd far above, that I perceive: 'tis dark,
But ſhe has ſuch a luſtre.

div.stage: Enter Iſmena and Aminta above with a Taper.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes Martine,
So radiant ſhe appears.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Elſe we may miſſe, Sir:
The night growes vengeance black, 'pray heaven ſhe ſhine clear:
Hark, hark, a window, and a candle too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Step cloſe, 'tis ſhe: I ſee the cloud diſperſe,
And now the beautious Planet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hah, 'tis indeed,
Now by the ſoul of love a divine Creature.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Sir, Sir,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Moſt bleſſed Lady.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: 'Pray ye ſtand out.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You need not fear, there's no body now ſtirring.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Beyond his commendation I am taken,
Infinite ſtrangely taken.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I love that Gentleman,
Methinks he has a dainty nimble body:
I love him heartily.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: 'Tis the right Gentleman:
But what to ſay to him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Speak.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wait ſtill,
And will do till I grow an other Pillar,
To propt this houſe, ſo it pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Speak ſoftly,
And 'pray ye ſpeak truly too.

sp.speaker: Ant,
sp.l: I never lyde, Lady.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: And don't think me impudent to ask ye,
I know ye are an Enemie, ſpeak low,
But I would make ye a friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am friend to beauty;
Ther's no handſomneſſe I dare be foe too.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Are ye married?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Are ye betrothed?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, neither.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Indeed (fair Sir.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Indeed (fair ſweet) I am not.
Moſt beauteous Virgin, I am free as you are.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: That may be Sir, then ye are miſerable,
For I am bound.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Happy the bonds that hold ye;
Or do you put them on your ſelf for pleaſure?
Sure they be ſweeter far then libertie:
There is no bleſſedneſſe but in ſuch bondage:
Give me that freedom (Madam) I beſeech ye,
(Since you have queſtion'd me ſo cunningly)
To ask you whom you are bound to, he muſt be certain
More then humane, that bounds in ſuch a beauty:
Happy that happy chain, ſuch links are heavenly.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Pray ye do not mock me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pray ye (Lady) tell me.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Will ye beleeve, and will ye keep it to ye?
And not ſcorn what I ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I dare not (Madam)
As Oracle what you ſay, I dare ſwear to.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I'll ſet the candle by: for I ſhall bluſh now;
Fy, how it doubles in my mouth? it muſt out,
'Tis you I am bound to.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speak that word again,
I underſtand ye not.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: 'Tis you I am bound to.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here is another gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: 'Tis you Sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He may belov'd too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not by thee, firſt curſe me.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: And if I knew your name.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Antonio (Madam)

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Antonio, take this kiſſe, 'tis you I am bound to.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And when I ſet ye free, may heaven forſake me, Iſmena.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Yes, now I perceive ye love me,
You have learnd my name.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hear but ſome vows I make to ye:
Hear but the proteſtations of a true love.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: No, no, not now: vowes ſhould be cheerful things,
Done in the cleereſt light, and nobleſt teſtimony:
No vow (deer Sir) tye not my fair belief
To ſuch ſtrict termes: thoſe men have broken credits,
Looſe and diſmembred faiths (my deer Antonio)
That ſplinter'em with vows: am I not too bold?
Correct me when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I had rather hear ye,
For ſo ſweet Muſick never ſtruck mine eares yet:
Will you believe now?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am yours.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Speak lowder,
If ye anſwer the Prieſt ſo low, you will loſe your wedding

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Would I might ſpeak, I would holloa.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Take my heart,
And if it be not firm and honeſt to you,
Heaven.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Peace, no more: I'll keep your heart, and credit it.
Keep you your word: when will you come again (Friend?)
For this time we have wooed indifferently,
I would fain ſee ye, when I dare be bolder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why any night: onely (deer noble Miſtris)
Pardon three daies: my Uncle Julio
Has bound me to attend him upon promile,
Upon expectation too: we have rare ſports there,
Rare Countrey ſports, I would you could but ſee'em.
Dare ye ſo honour me?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I dare not be there,
You know I dare not, no, I muſt not (friend)
Where I may come with honourable freedom:
Alas, I am ill too; wee in love.

sp.speaker: Ant,
sp.l: You flowt me.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Truſt me I do not: I ſpeak truth, I am ſickly,
And am in Love: but you muſt be Phyſician.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll make a plaiſter of my beſt affection.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Be gone, we have ſupp'd, I hear the people ſtir,
Take my beſt wiſhes: give me no cauſe (Antonio)
To curſe this hapyy night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll loſe my life firſt,
A thouſand kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Take ten thouſand back again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am dumb with admiration: ſhall we goe Sir? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Doſt thou know his Uncle?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: No, but I can ask, Coſen.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I'll tell thee more of that, come let's to bed both,
And give me handſom dreams, Love, I beſeech thee.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Has given ye a handſom ſubject.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Pluck to the windows. Exeunt.

l.hi: Six Chaires placed at the Arras.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: The thundring Seas, whoſe watry fire waſhes
The whiting mops:
The gentle Whale whoſe feet ſo fell
Flies ore the Mountains tops. within Franio.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Boy.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: The thundring.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why boy Buſtofa.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Here I am, the gentle whale. Ent. Franio.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Oh, are you here Sir? where's your ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: The gentle whale flies ore the mountain tops.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Where's your ſiſter (man)

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Waſhes the whiting-Mops.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Thou ly'ſt, ſhe has none to waſh mops?
The boy is half way out of his wits, ſure:
Sirrha, who am I?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: The thundring Seas.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Mad, ſtark mad.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Will you not give a man leave to con?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, and feſſe too, ere I have done with you Sirrha,
Am I your father?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: The queſtion is too hard for a child, ask me any thing
That I have learn'd, and I'll anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Is that a hard queſtion? Sirrha, am not I your Father?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: If I had my mother-wit I could tell you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Are you a thief?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: So far forth as the ſon of a Miller.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Will you be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Let it go by elderſhip. The gentle Whale.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sirrha, lay by your fooliſh ſtudy there,
And beat your brains about your owne affairs: or—

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I thank you; you'ld have me goe under the ſails
And beat my brains about your mill? a naturall
Father you are.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I charge you go not to the ſports to day:
Laſt night I gave you leave, now I recant.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Is the wind turn'd ſince laſt night?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Marry is it Sir, go no farther then my Mill;
There's my command upon you.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I may go round about then as your Mill does?
I will ſee your Mill gelded, and his Stones fryde in ſteaks,
Ere I deceive the Countrey ſo: have I not my part to ſtudy?
How ſhall the ſports go forward, if I be not there?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: They'll want their fool indeed, if thou bee'ſt not there.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Conſider that, and go your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I have fears (Sir) that I cannot utter,
You go not, nor your Siſter: there's my charge.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: The price of your golden thumb cannot hold me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I, this was ſport that I have tightly lov'd,
I could have kept company with the Hounds.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: You are fit for no other company yet.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Run with the Hare; and bin in the whore's tayl 'y faith:

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: That was before I was born, Ent. Otrante and Geraſto.
I did ever miſtruſt I was a Baſtard,
Becauſe Lapis is in the ſingular number with me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Leave thou that gun (Geraſto) and chaſe here,
Do thou but follow it with my deſires,
Thou'lt not return home emptie.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I am prepard
(My Lord) wjth advantages: and ſee
Yonder's the ſubject I muſt work upon:

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Her Brother? 'tis, methinks it ſhould be eaſie:
That groſſe compound cannot but diffuſe
The ſoul in ſuch a latitude of eaſe,
As to make dull her faculties, and lazie:
What wit above the leaſt can be in him,
That Reaſon ties together?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I have prov'd it, Sir,
And know the depth of it: I have the way
To make him follow me a hackney-pace,
With all that fleſh about him; yes, and dragge
His Siſter after him: This baytes the old one,
Rid you him, and leave me to the other. Exit

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: 'Tis well: O Franio, the good day to you;
You were not wont to hear this muſick ſtanding:
The Beagle and the Bugle ye have lov'd,
In the firſt rank of Huntſmen.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: The doggs cry out of him now.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sirrha, leave your barking, I'll bite you elſe:

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Curre, Curre.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Slave, do'ſt call me dog?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Oh ſie Sir, he ſpeaks Latine to you,
He would know why you'll bite him.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Reſponde cur; You ſee his underſtanding (my Lord)

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I ſhall have a time to curry you for this:
But (my Lord) to anſwer you, the daies have been
I muſt have footed it before this Horn-pipe,
Though I had hazarded my Mill a fire,
And let the ſtones grinde empty: but thoſe dancings
Are done with me: I have good will to it ſtill.
And that's the beſt I can do.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Come, come, you ſhall be hors'd:
Your company deſerves him, though you kil him,
Run him blind, I care not.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Hee'll do't o'purpoſe (my Lord) to bring him up to the Mill.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do not tempt me too far (my Lord)

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: There's a foot i'th' ſtirrop: I'll not leave you now:
You ſhall ſee the Game fall once again:

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Well (my Lord) I'll make ready my leggs for you,
And try'em once a horsback: ſirra: my charge, keep it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Yes, when you pare down your diſh for conſcience ſake.
When your thumb's coyn'd into bone & legalis,
When you are a true man-Miller.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: What's the matter Buſtofa?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: My Lord; if you have ere a drunken Jade that has the ſtaggers,
That will fall twice the height of our Mill with him: ſet him
O'th' back on him: a galled Jennet that will winch him out o' the
Saddle, and breake one on's necks, or a ſhank of him (there was
A fool going that way, but the Aſſe had better lucke;)
Or one of your brave Barbaries, that would paſſe the Straites, and run
Into his owne Countrey with him; the firſt Moor he met, would
Cut his throat for Complexions ſake: there's as deadly feud between
A Moor and a Miller, as between black and white.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Fie, fie, this is unnaturall Buſtofa,
Unleſſe on ſome ſtrong cauſe.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Be Judge (my Lord)
I am ſtudied in my part: the Julian-Feaſt is to day: the Countrey
Expects me; I ſpeak all the dumb ſhews: my ſiſter choſen for
A Nimp. The gentle Whale whoſe feet ſo fell: Cry mercy,
That was ſome of my part: But his charge is to keep the Mill,
And diſappoint the Revels.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.p: Indeed, there it ſpeaks ſhrewdly for thee; the Coun|try expecting.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I, and for mine own grace too.

sp.speaker: Ot.
sp.l: Yes, and being ſtudied too: and the main Speaker too.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: The main? why all my Speech lies in the main,
And the dry ground together: The thundring ſeas, whoſe, &c.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Nay, then thou muſt go, thou'lt be much condemn'd elſe.
But then o'th' other ſide, obedience.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Obedience?
But ſpeak your conſcience now (my Lord)
Am not I paſt asking bleſſing at theſe yeers?
Speak as you'r a Lord, if you had a Miller to your father.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I muſt yeeld to you (Buſtofa), your reaſons
Are ſo ſtrong, I cannot contradict: This I think,
If you go, your ſiſter ought to go along with you.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: There I ſtumble now: ſhee is not at age.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Why? ſhee's fifteen, and upwards.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: That's womans ripe age; as full as thou art
At one and twenty: ſhee's manable, is ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I think not: poor heart, ſhe was never tryde in my conſcience.
'Tis a coy thing; ſhe will not kiſſe you a clown, not if he
Would kiſſe her.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: What man?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Not if he would kiſſe her, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Oh, 'twas cleanlier then I expected: well Sir.
I'll leave you to your own, but my opinion is,
You may take her along: this is half way:
The reſt (Geraſto) and I hunt my prey.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Away with the old Miller (my Lord) and the mill Strikes ſail preſently.

div.stage: Enter Pedro, with Geraſto blind, ſinging.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Come follow me (you Country-Laſſes)
And you ſhall ſee ſuch ſport as paſſes:
You ſhall dance, and I will ſing;
Pedro hee ſhall rub the ſtring:
Each ſhall have a looſ-bodied gown
Of green; and laugh till you lie down.
Come follow me, come follow, &c.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: O ſweet Diego, the ſweeteſt Diego, ſtay: Si|ſter Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What's that, Brother?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Didſt not hear Diego? Hear him, and thou'lt be raviſh'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have heard him ſing, yet unraviſh'd, Brother.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: You had the better luck (Siſter.) I was raviſh'd
By mine own conſent: Come away: for the Sports.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have the fear of a Father on me (Brother.)

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Out: the theef is as ſafe as in his mill; hee's hunting with our
Great Land-lord, the Don Otrante. Strike up Diego.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But ſay he return before us, Where's our excuſe?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Strike up Diego. Haſt no ſtrings to thy apron?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Well, the fault lie upon your head (Brother).

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: My faults never mount ſo high (girl) they riſe but to
My middle at moſt. Strike up Diego.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Follow me by the ear, I'll lead thee on (Buſtofa) and
Pretty Florimell thy Siſter: oh that I could ſee her.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Oh Diego, there's two pities upon thee; great pitie thou art blinde;
And as great a pitie thou canſt not ſee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You ſhall have Crowns of Roſes, Dayſies,
Buds, where the honey-maker gazes:
You ſhall taſte the golden thighs,
Such as in wax-Chamber lies.
What fruit pleaſe you, taſte, freely pull,
Till you have all your bellies full.
Come follow me, &c.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: O Diego, the Don was not ſo ſweet when hee perfum'd the Steeple. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, how now (Friend) thou art not loſt agen?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not loſt? why, all the world's a wilderneſſe:
Some places peopled more by braver beaſts
Then others are: But faces, faces (man)
May a man be caught with faces?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Without wonder.
'Tis odds againſt him: May not a good face
Lead a man about by the noſe? 'las,
The noſe is but a part againſt the whole.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But is it poſſible that two faces
Should be ſo twin'd in form, complexion,
Figure, aſpect? that neither wen, nor mole,
The table of the brow, the eyes luſtre,
The lips cherry; neither the bluſh nor ſmile
Should give the one diſtinction from the other?
Do's Nature work in molds?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Altogether.
We are all one mold, one duſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thy reaſon's moldie.
I ſpeak from the Form, thou the Matter.
Why? was't not ever one of Natures Glories,
Nay, her great peece of wonder, that amongſt
So many millions millons of her works
Shee left the eye diſtinction, to cull out
The one from other; yet all one name, the face?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You muſt compare 'em by ſome other part
Of the body, if the face cannot do't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Didſt ask her name?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and who gave it her,
And what they promiſ'd more, beſides a ſpoon,
And what Apoſtles picture; ſhe is chriſtend too,
In token wherefore ſhe is call'd Iſabella,
The daughter of a Country plow-ſwain by:
If this be not true, ſhee lyes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She cannot;
It would be ſeen a bliſter on her lip,
Should falſhod touch it, it is ſo tender:
Had her name held, 't had been Iſmenia,
And not another of her name.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, if thou'lt ſpeak truth: Is ſhe not wondrous like?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As two garments of the ſame faſhion,
Cut from the ſame piece: yet if any excell,
This has the firſt; and in my judgement 'tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis my opinion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Were it the face
Where mine eye ſhould dwell, I would pleaſe both
With this, as ſoon as one with the other.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And yet the other is the caſe of this.
Had I not look'd upon Iſmenia,
I nere had ſtaid beyond good-morrows time
In view of this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Would I could leave him here,
'Twere a free paſſage to Iſmenia:
I muſt now blow, as to put out the fire
Yet kindle't more. You not conſider Sir,
The great diſparitie is in their bloods,
Eſtate and fortunes: there's the rich beauty
Which this poor homelineſſe is not endow'd with;
There's difference enough.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The leaſt of all.
Equalitie is no rule in Loves Grammar:
That ſole unhappineſſe is left to Princes
To marry blood: we are free dſpoſers,
And have the power to equalize their bloods
Up to our own; wee cannot keep it back,
'Tis a due debt from us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I Sir, had you
No Father nor Unkle, nor ſuch hinderers,
You might do with your ſelf at your pleaſure;
But as it is.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: As it is; 'tis nothing:
Their powers will come too late, to give me back
The yeſterday I loſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Indeed, to ſay ſooth,
Your oppoſition from the other part
Is of more force; there you run the hazzard
Of every hour a life, had you ſupply;
You meet your deereſt enemy in love
With all his hate about him: 'T will be more hard
For your Iſmenia to come home to you,
Then you to go to Country Iſabell. Enter Julio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tuſh; 'tis not fear removes me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No more: your Unkle.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, the good hour upon you Gentlemen:
Welcome Nephew; Speak it to your friend Sir,
It may be happier receiv'd from you,
In his acceptance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I made bold, Uncle,
To do it before; and I think he beleeves it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Twas never doubted, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Here are ſports (Dons)
That you muſt look on with a loving eye,
And without Cenſure, 'leſſe it be giving
My country neighbours loves their yeerly offrings
That muſt not be refus'd; though't be more pain
To the Spectator, then the painfull Actor,
'Twill abide no more teſt then the tinſell
Wee clad our Masks in for an hours wearing,
Or the Livory lace ſometimes on the cloaks
Of a great Dons Followers: I ſpeak no further
Then our own Country, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For my part, Sir,
The more abſurd, 't ſhalbe the better welcom.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You'll find the gueſt you look for: I heard Couſen,
You were at Toledo th'other day.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not late, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O fie! muſt I be plainer? You chang'd the point
With Tirſo and Liſauro, two of the Stock
Of our Antagoniſts, the Belides.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A meer proffer, Sir; the prevention
Was quick with us: we had done ſomewhat elſe:
This Gentleman was ingag'd in 't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am
The enemie to his foe for it: that wild-fire
Will crave more then fair water, to quench it
I ſuſpect. Whence it will come I know not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I was about a gentle reconcilement,
But I do fear I ſhall goe back agen.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come, come; The Sports are coming on us:
Nay, I have more gueſts to grace it: Welcome
Don Goſtanco, Giraldo, Philippo: Seat, ſeat all. Muſick.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Love is little, and therefore I preſent him, Enter a Cupid.
Love is a fire, therefore you may lament him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poor Love, who are they that can quench him?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He 's not without thoſe m●mbers, fear him not.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Love ſhoots, therefore I bear his bow about.
And Love is blind, therefore my eyes are out.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I never heard Love give reaſon for what he did be|fore.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Let ſuch as can ſee, ſee ſuch as cannot: behold,
Our goddeſſes all three ſtrive for the ball of gold:
And here fair Paris comes, the hopefull youth of Troy,
Queen Hecub's darling-ſon, King Priams onely joy.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Is this Paris? I ſhould have taken him for He|ctor rather.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Paris at this time: Pray you hold your prating.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Paris can be angry.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, at this time
You muſt pardon him; he comes as a Judge.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: —Mercy on all that looks upon him, ſay I.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: The thundring ſeas whoſe watry fire waſhes the whiting-Mops,
The gentle Whale, whoſe feet ſo fell, flies ore the mountain tops.
No roares ſo fierce, no throats ſo deep, no howls can bring ſuch fears
As Paris can, if Garden from he call his Dogs and Bears.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I, thoſe they were that I feard all this while.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Yes Jack-an-Apes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I thank you, good Paris.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: You may hold your peace, and ſtand further out o'th' way then:
The lines will fall where they light,
Yes Jack-an-Apes, he hath to ſports, and faces make like mirth,
Whilſt bellowing buls, the horned beaſts, do toſſe from ground to earth:
Bloud Bear there is, as Cupid blind.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That Bear would be whip'd for loſing of his eyes.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Be whipped man may ſee,
But we preſent no ſuch content, but Nimps ſuch as they be.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Theſe are long lines.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Can you blame him, leading Buls & Bears in 'em?

div.stage: Enter Shepherd ſinging, with Iſmena, Aminta, Florimell, (as Juno, Pallas, Venus,) and 3 Nymphs attending.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Go Cupid blind, conduct the dumb, for Ladies muſt not ſpeak here:
Let ſhepherds ſing with dancing feet, and cords of muſick break here. Song.
Now Ladies fight, with heels ſo light, by lot your luck muſt fall,
Where Paris pleaſe, to do you eaſe, and give the golden Ball. Dance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If you plaid Paris now Antonio, where would you beſtow it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I prethee, Friend,
Take the full freedome of thought, but no words.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Proteſt there's a third, which by her habit
Should perſonate Venus, and by conſequence
Of the Story, receive the honours prize:
And were I a Paris, there it ſhould be.
Doe you note her?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No; mine eye is ſo fixed,
I cannot move it.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: The dance is ended; Now to judgment Paris.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Here Juno, here: but ſtay, I do eſpy
A pretty gleeke comming from Pallas eye:
Here Pallas, here: yet ſtay agen: methinks
I ſee the eye of lovely Venus winks:
Oh cloſe them both: ſhut in thoſe golden eyne,
And I will kiſſe thoſe ſweet blind cheeks of thine.
Juno is angry: yes, and Pallas frowns,
Would Paris now were gone from Ida's-downe.
They both are fair, but Venus has the Mole,
The faireſt hair, and ſweeteſt dimple hole:
To her, or her, or her, or her, or neither;
Can one man pleaſe three Ladies altogether?
No, take it Venus, toſſe it at thy pleaſure,
Thou art the lovers friend beyond his meaſure.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Paris has done what man can do, pleas'd one,
Who can do more? Enter Geraſto, (as Mars)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay, here's another perſon.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Come lovely Venus, leave this lower Orbe,
And mount with Mars, up to his glorious Spheare.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: How now, what's he:

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I'm ignorant what to do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thy ſilver-yoke of Doves are in the Team,
And thou ſhalt fly through Apollo's Beam:
I'le ſee thee ſeated in thy golden Throne,
And hold with Mars a ſweet conjunction. Exit.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Ha? what follows this? has carried away my ſiſter Venus:
He never rehears'd his part with me before.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What follows now Prince Paris?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Hue and cry, I think Sir this is Venus voice,
Mine owne ſiſter Florinells.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What is there ſome Tragick-Act behind?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: No, no, altogeth●r Comical; Mars and Venus
Are in the old conjunction it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis very improper then, for Venus
Never cryes out when ſhe conjoynes with Mars.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: That's true indeed: they are out of their parts ſure,
It may be 'tis the Book-holders fault: Ile go ſee.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How like you our Countrey Revells, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: All Gent.
sp.l: Oh, they commend themſelves, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Me-thinks now
Juno and Minerva ſhould take revenge on Paris,
It cannot end without it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I did expect
Inſteed of Mars, the Storm-Gaoler Eolus,
And Juno proffring her Deiopeia
As ſatisfaction to the bluſtring god,
To ſend his Toſſers forth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It may ſo follow,
Lets not prejudicate the Hiſtory. Enter Buſtofa.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So, here's a Paſſion towards.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Help, help, if you be Gentlemen; my Siſter,
My Venus; ſhee's ſtolne away.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The ſtory changes from our expectation,

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Help, my father the Miller will hang me els: god Mars
Is a bawdy Villain: he ſaid ſhe ſhould ride upon Doves:
Shee's horſs'd, ſhee's horſs'd whether ſhe will or no.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sure I think hee's ſerious.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: She's horſs'd upon a double Gelding, and a Stone-horſe in the breech
Of her: the poor wench cries help, and I cry help, & none
Of you will help.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Speak, is it the ſhow, or doſt thou bawle?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: A pox on the Ball: my Siſter bawls, and I bawl:
Either bridle horſe and follow, or give me a halter
To hang my ſelf: I cannot run ſo faſt as a hogge.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Wie follow me, I'le fill the Countrey with purſuit
But I will find the Thief: my Houſe thus abus'd?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: 'Tis my houſe that's abus'd, the Siſter of my fleſh and blood: oh, oh. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1. Wench.
sp.p: Tis time we all ſhift for our ſelves if this be ſerious.

sp.l: However I'le be gone.
And I. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You need not fright your beauties pretty ſouls,
With the leaſt pale complexion of a fear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Juno has better courage: and Minerva more di|ſcreet.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Alas my courage was ſo counterfeit
It might have been ſtruck from me with a feather,
Juno ne'er had ſo weak a preſenter.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sure I was ne'er the wiſer for Minerva,
That I find yet about me.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: My dwelling, Sir?
'Tis a poor Yeomans roof, ſcarce a league off,
That never ſham'd me yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your gentle pardon:
I vow my erring eyes had almoſt caſt you
For one of the moſt mortal Enemies
That our Family has.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I'me ſorty Sir,
I am ſo like your foe: 'twere fit I haſted
From your offended ſight.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh, miſtake not,
It was my error, and I do confeſſe it:
You'l not beleeve your welcome; nor can I ſpeak it;
But there's my friend can tell you, pray hear him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I tell her Sir? I'me glad of the employment.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A kinſwoman to that beauty:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A kin to her, Sir,
But nothing to her Beauty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do not wrong it, 'tis not far behind her.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Her hinder parts are not far off, indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let me but kiſſe you with his ardour now,
You ſhall feel how he loves you.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Oh forbear:
'Tis not the faſhion with us, but would you
Perſwade me that he loves me?

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.l: I'le warrant you
He dies in't: and that were witnes enough on't.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Love me Sir? can you tell me for what reaſon?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fy, will ye ask me that which you have about you?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I know nothing Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let him find it then;
He conſtantly beleeves you have the thing
That he muſt love you for: much is apparent,
A ſweet and lovely beauty.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: So Sir; Pray you
Show me one thing: Did he nere love before?
(I know you are his boſome-Counſellor)
Nay then I ſee your anſwer is not ready:
I'le not beleeve you if you ſtudy farther.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I ſpeak truth to you?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Or ſpeak no more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There was a ſmile thrown at him, from a Lady
Whoſe deſerts might buy him treble, and lately
He receiv'd it, and I know where he loſt it,
In this face of yours: I know his heart's within you.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: May I know her name?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In your ear you may
With vow of ſilence.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hee'l not give over Sir:
If he ſpeak for you, hee'l ſure ſpeed for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But that's not the anſwer to my queſtion.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You are the firſt in my virgin-conſcence
That ere ſpoke Love to her: oh, my heart!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How doe you?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Nothing Sir: but would I had a better face.
How well yoor pulſe beats.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Healthfully, does it not?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: It thumps prettily, me thinks.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Alack, I hear it
With much pitie: how great is your fault too,
In wrong to the good Lady?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You forget
The difficult paſſage hee has to her,
A hell of feud's between the Families.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: and that has often Love wrought by advantage
To peacefull reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: This way 'tis worſer; 't may ſeed again in her
Unto another generation:
For where (poor Lady) is her ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It comes in me; to be truth, I love her
(I'll go no farther for compariſon)
As deer as hee loves you.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: How if ſhee love not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tuſh: be that my pains: You know not what art
I have thoſe wayes.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Beſhrow you, you have practiſ'd upon me,
Well, ſpeed me here, and you with your Iſmenia.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Go, the condition's drawn, ready dated,
There wants but your hand to 't.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Truly you have taken great pains, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A friendly part, no more (ſweet Beuty.)

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: They are happy, Sir, have ſuch friends as you are.
But do you know you have done well in this?
How will his Allyes receive it? ſhee (though I ſay't)
Is of no better Blood then I am.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There I leave it, I'm at fartheſt that way.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: You ſhall extend your vows no larger now.
My heart calls you mine own: and that's enough.
Reaſon, I know, would have all yet conceal'd.
I ſhall not leave you unſaluted long
Either by pen or perſon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You may diſcourſe
With me, when you think y'are alone, I ſhall
Be preſent with you.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Come Coſen, will you walk?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Alas, I was ready long ſince: in conſcience
You would with better will yet ſtay behind.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Oh Love, I never thought thou'dſt bin ſo blind.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You'll anſwer this Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If ere 't be ſpoke on: Enter Julio.
I purpoſe not to propound the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis true the poor knave ſaid: ſome Raviſher,
Some of Luſts Blood-hounds have ſeiz'd upon her:
The Girle is hurried, as the divell were with 'em
And help'd their ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It may be not ſo ill, Sir.
A well prepared Lover may do as much
In hot blood as this, and perform't honeſtly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What? ſteale away a virgin 'gainſt her will?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It may be any mans caſe; deſpiſe nothing:
And that's a thiefe of a good quality,
Moſt commonly hee brings his theft home again,
Though with a little ſhame.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: There's a charge by 't
Faln upon mee: Paris (the Millers ſon)
Her brother, dares not venture home again
Till better tidings follow of his ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Y'are the more beholding to the miſchance, Sir:
Had I gone a Boot-haling, I ſhould as ſoon
Have ſtolne him, as his ſiſter: Marry then,
To render him back in the ſame plight he is
May be coſtly: his fleſh is not maintain'd with little.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I think the poor knave will pine away,
Hee cries all to be pitied yonder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray you Sir, let's go ſee him: I ſhould laugh
To ſee him cry ſure.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Well, you are merry, Sir.
Antonio, keep this charge; I have fears
Move me to lay it on you: Pray forbear
The wayes of your enemies, the Bellides.
I have reaſon for my Injunction, Sir. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Aminta (as a Page with a Letter.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To me, Sir? from whom?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A friend, I dare vow, Sir.
Though on the enemies part: the Ladie Iſmenia.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take heed: bluſh not too deep: let me adviſe you
In your Anſwer, 't muſt be done heedfully.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I ſhould not ſee a maſculine in peace
Out of that houſe.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Alas: I' am a child, Sir,
Your hates cannot laſt till I wear a ſword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Await me for your anſwer.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hee muſt ſee her,
To manifeſt his ſhame: 'tis my advantage;
While our blood 's under us, wee keep above:
But then we fall when we do fall in love. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, your houſe hath injur'd me,
Rob'd me of all the joyes I had on earth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Where wert thou brought up (fellow)?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: In a Mill.
You may perceive it by my loud exclaims,
Which muſt riſe higher yet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Obſtreperous Carle.
If thy throats tempeſt could ore-turn my houſe,
What ſatisfaction were it for thy child?
Turn thee the right way to thy journies end.
Wilt have her where ſhe is not?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Here was ſhe loſt,
And here muſt I begin my footing after;
From whence, untill I meet a pow'r to puniſh,
I will not reſt: You are not quick to grief,
Your hearing 's a dead ſenſe. Were yours the loſſe,
Had you a daughter ſtoln, perhaps be-whor'd.
(For to what other end ſhould come the thiefe)?
You'ld play the Miller then, be loud and high.
But being not a ſorrow of your own,
You have no help nor pitie for another,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, thou haſt op'd a ſluce was long ſhut up,
And let a flood of grief in; a buried grief
Thy voice hath wak'd again: a grief as old
As likely t'is, thy child is; friend; I tell thee,
I did once loſe a daughter.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Did you Sir?
Beſeech you then, how did you bear her loſſe?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: With thy grief trebled,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But was ſhe ſtolne from you?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, by devouring theeves, from whom cannot
Ever returne a ſatisfaction:
The wild beaſts had her in her ſwathing clothes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Oh much good do'em with her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Away tough churle.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why, ſhe was better eaten then my child,
Better by beaſts then beaſtly men devoured,
They took away a life, no honour from her:
Thoſe beaſts might make a Saint of her, but theſe
Will make my child a devil: but was ſhe, Sir,
Your onely daughter?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I ne'r had other (Friend)

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: Where are you (man?) your buſines lies not here,
Your daughter's in the Pownd, I have found where.
'Twill coſt you deer her freedom.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I'll break it down,
And free her without pay:
Horſe-locks nor chains ſhall hold her from me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll take this relief,
I now have time to ſpeak alone with grief. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How? my Land-lord? hee's Lord of my Lands
But not my Cattel: I'll have her again (Gill)

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: You are not mad upon the ſudden now.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: No Gill, I have been mad theſe five hours:
I'll ſell my Mill, and buy a Roring,
I'll batter down his houſe, and make a Stewes on't,

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Will you gather up your wits a little
And hear me? the King's neer by in progreſſe,
Here I have got our ſupplication drawn,
And there's the way to help us.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Give it me (Gill,)
I will not fear to give it to the King:
To his own hands (God bleſſe him) will I give it,
And he ſhall ſet the Law upon their ſhoulders,
And hang 'em all that had a hand in it.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Where's your Son?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He ſhall be hang'd in flotches:
The dogs ſhall eat him in Lent, there's Cats-meat
And Dogs-meat enough about him.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Sure the poor girle is the Counts whore by this time.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: If ſhe be the Counts whore, the whores Count
Shall pay for it: He ſhall pay for a new Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: You are ſo violous: this I'm reſolv'd,
If ſhe be a whore once, I'll renounce her,
You know, if every man had his right,
She's none of our child, but a meer foundling,
(And I can gueſſe the owner for a need too)
We have but foſterd her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Gill, no more of that,
I'll cut your tongue out if you tell thoſe tales.
Hark, hark, theſe Toaters tell us the King's coming:
Get you gone; I'll ſee if I can find him. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Liſauro, Terſa, Pedro and Moncado.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Do's the King remove to day?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: So ſaies the Harbengers,
And keeps his way on to Valentia,
There ends the progreſſe.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He hunts this morning Gentlemen,
And dines i'th' fields: the Court is all in readineſſe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Pedro, did you ſend for this Tailor? or you Moncado?
This light french-demi-launce that follows us,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: No, I aſſure ye on my word, I am guiltleſſe,
I owe him too much to be inward with him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am not quit I am ſure: there is a reckoning
Of ſome four ſcarlet cloaks, and two lac'd ſuits
Hangs on the file ſtill, like a fearful Comet
Makes me keep off.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I am in too Gentlemen,
I thank his faith, for a matter of three hundred.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: And I for two, what a devil makes he this way?
I do not love to ſee my ſins before me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: 'Tis the vacation, and theſe things break out
To ſee the Court, and glory in their debtors.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What do you call him for? I never love
To remember their names that I owe money to,
'Tis not gentill, I ſhun'em like the plague ever.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: His name's Vertigo: hold your heads, and wonder,
A French-man, and a founder of new faſhions:
The Revolutions of all ſhapes and habits
Run madding through his brains. Ent. Vertigo.

sp.speaker: Monc.
sp.l: He is very brave.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: The ſhreds of what he ſteals from us beleeve it,
Makes him a mighty man: he comes, have at ye.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Save ye together, my ſweet Gentlemen,
I have been looking—

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Not for money Sir?
You know the hard time.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pardon me ſweet (Signior)
Good faith the leaſt thought in my heart, your love Gentlemen,
Your love's enough for me: Money? hang money:
Let me preſerve your love.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Yes marry ſhall ye,
And we our credit, you would ſee the Court?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: He ſhall ſee every place.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Shall I i'faith Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The Gellar, and the Buttry, and the Kitchin,
The Paſtry, and the Pantry.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I, and taſte too
Of every Office: and be free of all too:
That he may ſay when he comes home in glory,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And I will ſay, i'faith, and ſay it openly,
And ſay it home too: Shall I ſee the King alſo?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Shalt ſee him every day: ſhalt ſee the Ladies
In their French clothes: ſhalt ride a hunting with him,
Shalt have a Miſtris too: we muſt fool hanſomly
To keep him in belief, we honour him,
He may call on us elſe.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A pox upon him.
Let him call at home in's owne houſe for ſalt butter,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And when the King puts on a new ſuit.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt ſee it firſt,
And deſect his dublets, that thou maiſt be perfect.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The Wardrobe I would fain view, Gentlemen,
Fain come to ſee the Wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt ſee it,
And ſee the ſecret of it, dive into it:
Sleep in the Wardrobe, and have Revelations
Of faſhions five yeer hence.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ye honour me;
Ye infinitely honour me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Any thing i'th' Court Sir,
Or within the compaſſe of a Courtier,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My wife ſhall give ye thanks.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You ſhall ſee any thing,
The privatſt place, the ſtool, and where 'tis emptied.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ye make me bluſh, ye pour your bounties, Gentlemen,
In ſuch abundance.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I will ſhow thee preſently
The order that the King keeps when he comes
To open view; that thou maiſt tell thy Neighbours
Over a ſhoulder of mutton, thou haſt ſeen ſomthing,
Nay, thou ſhalt preſent the King for this time.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Nay, I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: That thou maiſt know what State there do's belong to it;
Stand there I ſay, and put on a ſad countenance,
Mingled with height: be cover'd, and reſerved;
Move like the Sun, by ſoft degrees, and glorious,
Into your order (Gentlemen) uncover'd,
The King appears; Wee'l ſport with you a while Sir,
I am ſure you are merry with us all the year long (Tailor)
Move ſofter ſtill, keep in that fencing leg; Monſieur,
Turne to no ſide.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What's this that appears to him?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: 'Has a petition, and he looks moſt lamentably,
Miſtake him, and we are made.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This is the King ſure,
The glorious King, I know him by his gay clothes.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Now bear your ſelf that you may ſay hereafter.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I have recover'd breath, I'll ſpeak unto him preſently,
May it pleaſe your gracious majeſty to conſider
A poor mans caſe?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What's your will Sir?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: You muſt accept, and read it.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: The Tailor will run mad upon my life for't.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How he mumps and bridles: he will ne'er cut clothes again.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And what's your grief?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: He ſpeaks i'th' noſe like his gooſe.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I pray you read there; I am abus'd, and frumpt Sir,
By a great man that may do ill by authority;
Poor honeſt men are hang'd for doing leſſe Sir,
My child is ſtolne, the Count Otrante ſtole her;
A pretty child ſhe is, although I ſay it,
A hanſom mother, he means to make a whore of her,
A ſilken whore, his knaves have filch'd her from me;
He keeps lewd knaves, that do him beaſtly offices:
I kneel for Juſtice. Shall I have it Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What Pageant's this?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: The King:
Tailor, ſtand off, here ends your apparition:
Miller, turn round, and there addreſſe your paper,
There, there's the King indeed.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May it pleaſe your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why didſt thou kneel to that fellow?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: In good faith Sir,
I thought he had been a King he was ſo gallant:
There's none here wears ſuch gold.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: So fooliſhly,
You have golden buſines ſure; becauſe I am homely
Clad, in no glittring ſuit, I'am not look'd on:
Ye fools that wear gay clothes love to be gap'd at,
What are you better when your end calls on you?
Will gold preſerve ye from the grave? or jewells?
Get golden minds, and fling away your Trappings
Unto your bodies, miniſter warm rayments,
Wholſom and good; glitter within and ſpare not:
Let my Court have rich ſouls, their ſuits I weigh not:
And what are you that took ſuch State upon ye?
Are ye a Prince?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: The Prince of Tailors, Sir,
We owe ſome money to him, and 't like your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If it like him, would ye owde more, be modeſter,
And you leſſe ſawcy Sir: and leave this place:
Your preſſing iron will make no perfect Courtier:
Go ſtitch at home, and cozen your poor neighbours,
Show ſuch another pride, I'll have ye whipt for't,
And get worſe clothes, theſe but proclaim your fellony.
And what's your paper?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I beſeech you read it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's here? the Count Otrante task'd for a baſe villany,
For ſtealing of a maid?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The Count Otrante?
Is not the fellow mad Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: No, no, my Lord,
I am in my wits, I am a labouring man,
And we have ſeldom leiſure to run mad,
We have other buſineſſe to employ our heads in,
We have little wit to loſe too: if we complain,
And if a heavie lord lie on our ſhoulders,
Worſe then a ſack of meal, and oppreſſe our poverties,
We are mad ſtraight, and whop'd, and tyde in fetters,
Able to make a horſe mad as you uſe us,
You are mad for nothing, and no man dare proclaim it,
In you a wildneſſe is a noble trick,
And cheriſhd in ye, and all men muſt love it:
Oppreſſions of all ſorts, ſit like new clothes,
Neatly and hanſomly upon your Lordſhips:
And if we kick when your honours ſpur us,
We are knaves and Jades, and ready for the Juſtice.
I am a true Miller.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then thou art a wonder.

sp.speaker: 2 L.
sp.l: I know the man reputed for a good man
An honeſt and ſubſtantial fellow.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He ſpeaks ſence,
And to the point: Greatneſſe begets much rudeneſſe.
How dare you (Sirrha) 'gainſt ſo main a perſon,
A man of ſo much Noble note and honour,
Put up this baſe complaint? Muſt every Peſant
Upon a ſawcy will affront great Lords!
All fellows (Miller?)

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I have my reward, Sir,
I was told one greatneſſe would protect another,
As beams ſupport their fellowes; now I find it:
If 't pleaſe your Grace to have me hang'd, I am ready,
Tis but a Miller, and a Thief diſpatch'd:
Though I ſteal bread, I ſteal no fleſh to tempt me.
I have a wife, and 't pleaſe him to have her too,
With all my heart; 't will make my charge the leſſe Sir,
She'll hold him play a while: I have a Boy too,
He is able to inſtruct his Honours hoggs,
Or rub his Horſe-heels: when it pleaſe his Lordſhip
He may make him his ſlave too, or his bawd:
The boy is well bred, can exhort his Siſter:
For me, the priſon, or the Pillory,
To loſe my goods, and have mine ears cropt off:
Whipt like a Topp, and have a paper ſtuck before me,
For abominable honeſtie to his owne daughter,
I can endure, Sir: the Miller has a ſtout heart,
Tough as his Toal-pin.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I ſuſpect this ſhrewdly,
Is it his daughter that the people call
The Millers fair maid?

sp.speaker: 2 Lo.
sp.l: It ſhould ſeem ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be ſure you be i'th' right, Sirrha.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: If I be i'th' wrong Sir,
Be ſure you hang me, I will ask no curteſie:
Your Grace may have a daughter, think of that Sir,
She may be fair, and ſhe may be abuſed too:
A King is not exempted from theſe caſes:
Stolne from your loving care.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I do much pity him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But heaven forbid ſhe ſhould be in that venture
That mine is in at this hour: I'll aſſure your Grace
The Lord wants a water-mill, & means to grind with her
Would I had his ſtones to ſet, I would fit him for it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Follow me (Miller) and let me talk with ye farther,
And keep this private all upon your loyalties:
To morrow morning, though I am now beyond him,
And the leſſe lookt for, I'll break my faſt with good Count.
No more, away, all to our ſports, be ſilent. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What Grace ſhall I have now?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Chooſe thine owne grace,
And go to dinner when thou wilt, Vertigo,
We muſt needs follow the King.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You heard the ſentence.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: If you ſtay here
I'll ſend thee a ſhoulder of Veniſon:
Go home, go home, or if thou wilt diſguiſe,
I'll help thee to a place to feed the dogs.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Or thou ſhalt be ſpecial Tailor to the Kings Monkey,
'Tis a fine place, we cannot ſtay.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No money,
Nor no grace (Gentlemen?)

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: 'Tis top early Taylor.
The King has not broke his faſt yet.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I ſhall look for ye
The next Terme, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not miſſe us:
Prethee provide ſome clothes, and doſt thou hear Vertigo,
Commend me to thy wife: I want ſome ſhirts too.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I have Chambers for ye all.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: They are too muſty,
When they are cleer wee'l come.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I muſt be patient
And provident, I ſhall never get home els. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Prethee be wiſer wench, thou canſt not ſcape me,
Let me with love and gentleneſſe enjoy that
That may be ſtill preſerv'd with love, and long'd for,
If violence lay rough hold, I ſhall hate thee,
And after I have enjoyd thy Maiden-head,
Thou wilt appear ſo ſtale and ugly to me
I ſhall deſpiſe thee, caſt thee off.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I pray ye, Sir,
Begin it now, and open your dores to me,
I do confeſſe I am ugly; Let me go, Sir:
A Gipſey-girl: Why would your Lordſhip touch me?
Fye, 'tis not noble: I am homely bred,
Courſe, and unfit for you: why do you flatter me?
There be young Ladies, many that will love ye,
That will dote on ye: you are a hanſome Gentleman,
What will they ſay when once they know your quality?
A Lord, a Miller? take your Toal-diſh with ye:
You that can deal with Gudgins, and courſe floure,
'Tis pitie you ſhould taſte what manchet means:
Is this fit Sir, for your repute and honour?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I'll love thee ſtill.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You cannot, there's no ſympathy
Between our births, our breeding, arts, conditions,
And where theſe are at difference, there's no liking:
This houre it may be I ſeem hanſom to you,
And you are taken with variety
More then with beauty: to morrow when you have enjoy'd me,
Your heate and luſt aſſwag'd, and come to examine
Out of cold and penitent condition
What you have done, whom you have ſhar'd your love with,
Made partner of your bed, how it will vex ye,
How you will curſe the devil that betrayd ye:
And what ſhall become of me then?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Wilt thou hear me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: As haſtie as ●ou were then to enjoy me,
As precious as this beauty ſhew'd unto ye,
You'll kick me out of dores, you will whore and ban me:
And if I prove with child with your fair iſſue,
Give me a penſion of five pound a yeer
To breed your heir withall, and ſo good ſpeed me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I'll keep thee like a woman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'll keep my ſelf Sir,
Keep my ſelf honeſt Sir; there's the brave keeping:
If you will marry me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Alas poor Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I do confeſſe I am too courſe and baſe Sir
To be your wife, and it is fit you ſcorn me,
Yet ſuch as I have crown'd the lives of great ones:
To be your whore, I am ſure I am too worthy,
(For by my troth Sir, I am truly honeſt)
And that's an honour equal to your greatnes.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I'll give thee what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Tempt me no more then:
Give me that peace, and then you give abundance,
I know ye do but try me, ye are noble,
All theſe are but to try my modeſtie,
If you ſhould find me eaſie, and once coming,
I ſee your eies already how they would fright me:
I ſee your honeſt heart how it would ſwell
And burſt it ſelf into a grief againſt me:
Your tongue in noble anger, now, even now Sir,
Ready to rip my looſe thoughts to the bottom,
And lay my ſhame unto my ſelf, wide open:
You are a noble Lord: you pity poor maids,
The people are miſtaken in your courſes:
You, like a father, try'em to the uttermoſt.
As they do gold: you purge the droſſe from them,
And make them ſhine.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: This cunning cannot help ye:
I love ye to enjoy ye: I have ſtolne ye
To enjoy ye now, not to be fool'd with circumſtance,
Yeeld willingly, or elſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I will force ye.
I will not be delay'd, a poor baſe wench
That I in curteſie make offer to,
Argue with me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Do not, you will loſe your labour,
Do not (my Lord) it will become ye poorly
Your curteſie may do much on my nature,
For I am kind as you are, and as tender:
If you compell, I have my ſtrengths to fly to,
My honeſt thoughts, and thoſe are guards about me:
I can cry too, and noiſe enough I dare make,
And I have curſes, that will call down thunder,
For all I am a poor wench, heaven will hear me:
My body you may force, but my will never;
And be ſure I do not live if you do force me,
Or have no tongue to tell your beaſtly Story,
For if I have, and if there be a Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Pray ye go in here: I'll calme my ſelf for this time.
And be your friend again.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am commanded. Exit.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You cannot ſcape me, yet I muſt enjoy ye,
I'll lie with thy wit, though I miſſe thy honeſty:
Is this a wench for a Boors hungry boſom?
A morſel for a Peaſants baſe embraces?
And muſt I ſtarve, and the meat in my mouth?
I'll none of that. Enter Geraſto.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: How now my Lord, how ſped ye?
Have ye done the deed?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: No, pox upon't, ſhe is honeſt.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Honeſt? what's that? you take her bare deniall,
Was there ever wench brought up in a mill, and honeſt?
That were a wonder worth a Chronicle,
Is your belief ſo large? what did ſhe ſay to ye?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: She ſaid her honeſty was all her dowry,
And preach'd unto me, how unfit, and homely,
Nay how diſhonourable it would ſeem in me
To act my will; popt me i'th mouth with modeſtie.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What an impudent Quean was that? that's their trick ever.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: And then diſcours'd to me very learnedly
What fame and loud opinion would tell of me:
A wife ſhe touch'd at.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Out upon her Varlet.
Was ſhe ſo bold? theſe home ſpun things are devils,
They'll tell ye a thouſand lies, if you'll beleeve'em;
And ſtand upon their honours like great Ladies,
They'll ſpeak unhappily too: good words to cozen ye,
And outwardly ſeem Saints: they'll cry down-right alſo,
But 'tis for anger that you do not cruſh 'em.
Did ſhe not talk of being with child?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: She toucht at it,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: The trick of an arrant whore to milk your Lordſhip
And then a penſion nam'd?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: No, no, ſhe ſcorn'd it:
I offer'd any thing, but ſhe refus'd all,
Refus'd it with a confident hate.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You thought ſo,
You ſhould have taken her then, turn'd her, and tew'd her
I'th' ſtrength of all her reſolution, flattered her,
And ſhak't her ſtubborn will: ſhe would have thank'd ye,
She would have lov'd ye infinitely, they muſt ſeem modeſt,
It is their parts: if you had plaid your part Sir.
And handled her as men do unmand Hawks,
Caſt her, and malde her-up in good clean linnen:
And there have coyed her, you had caught her heart-ſtrings
Theſe tough Virginities they blow like white thornes
In Stormes and Tempeſts.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: She is beyond all this,
As cold, and harden'd, as the Virgin Cryſtal.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Oh force her, force her, Sir, ſhe longs to be raviſhd
Some have no pleaſure but in violence;
To be torne in pieces is their paradiſe:
'Tis ordinary in our Country, Sir, to raviſh all
They will not give a penny for their ſport
Unleſſe they be put to it, and terribly,
And then they ſwear they'll hang the man comes neer'em,
And ſwear it on his lips too.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: No, no forcing,
I have an other courſe, and I will follow it,
I command you, and do you command your fellows,
That when you ſee her next, diſgrace, and ſcorn her,
Ill ſeem to put her out o'th' dores o'th' ſodain
And leave her to conjecture, then ſeize on her
Away, be ready ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We ſhall not fail, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I am ſure you have now conſider'd
And like a wiſe wench weigh'd a friends diſpleaſure,
Repented your prowd thoughts, and caſt your ſcorn off.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My Lord, I am not proud, I was never beautifull.
Nor ſcorn I any thing that's juſt and honeſt.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Come, to be ſhort, can ye love yet? you told me
Kindnes would far compell ye: I am kind to ye,
And mean to exceed that way.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I told ye too, Sir,
As far as it agreed with modeſtie,
With honour, and with honeſty I would yeeld to yee:
Good my Lord, take ſome other Theam: for Love,
Alas, I never knew yet what it meant,
And on the ſudden Sir, to run through volumes
Of his moſt myſtick art, 'tis moſt impoſſible;
Nay, to begin with luſt, which is an Heriſie,
A foul one too; to learn that in my childhood▪
O good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You will not out of this ſong,
Your modeſtie, and honeſtie, is that all?
I will not force ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ye are too noble, Sir.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Nor play the childiſh fool, and marry ye,
I am yet not mad.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If ye did, men would imagine.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Nor will I woo ye at that infinite price
It may be you expect.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I expect your pardon,
And a diſcharge (my Lord) that's all I look for.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: No, nor fall ſick for love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis a healthful year Sir.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Look ye, I'l turn ye out o'dores, and ſcorn ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thank ye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: A proud ſlight Peat I found ye,
A fool (it may be too.)

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: An honeſt woman,
Good my Lord think me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: And a baſe I leave ye,
So fare-ye-well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Bleſſing attend your Lordſhip;
This is hot love, that vaniſheth like vapors;
His Ague's off, his burning fits are well quench'd,
I thank heaven for't: his men, they will not force me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What doſt thou ſtay for? doſt thou not know the way,
Thou baſe unprovident whore?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good words, pray ye Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Has my Lord ſmoak'd ye over, good wife Miller?
Is your Mill broken that you ſtand ſo uſeleſſe?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: An impudent Quean, upon my life ſhe is unwholſome;
Some baſe diſcarded thing my Lord has found her,
He would not have turnd her off o'th'ſudden elſe.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now againſt every ſack (my honeſt ſweet-heart)
With every Sim and Smug.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I muſt be patient.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And every greaſie gueſt, and ſweaty Raſcall
For his Royal hire between his fingers, Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: I feare thou haſt given my Lord the— thou damn'd thing.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: I have ſeen her in the Stewes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: The knave her father
Was Bawd to her there, and kept a Tipling houſe,
You muſt even to it again: a modeſt function.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If ye had honeſty, ye would not uſe me
Thus baſely wretchedly, though your Lord bid ye,
But he that knows.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away thou carted impudence,
You meat for every man: a little meal
Flung in your face, makes ye appear ſo proud.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This is inhumane. Let theſe tears perſwade you
If ye be men, to uſe a poor girle better:
I wrong not you, I am ſure I call you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: What buſines is here? away, are not you gone yet?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My Lord, this is not well: although you hate me,
For what I know not: to let your people wrong me,
Wrong me maliciouſly, and call me

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Peace,
And mark me what we ſay adviſedly;
Mark, as you love that that you call your credit;
Yeeld now, or you are undone: your good name's periſh'd
Not all the world can buy your reputation;
Tis ſunk for ever els, theſe peoples tongues will poiſon ye
Though you be white as innocence, they'll taint ye,
They will ſpeak terrible and hideous things,
And people in this age are prone to credit,
They'll let fell nothing that may brand a woman,
Conſider this, and then be wiſe and tremble:
Yeeld yet, and yet I'll ſave ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I'll ſhow ye,
Their mouthes I'll ſeal up, they ſhall ſpeak no more
But what is honourable and honeſt of ye,
And Saintlike they ſhall worſhip ye: they are mine,
And what I charge 'em Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am ruind,
Heaven will regard me yet, they are barbarous wretches:
Let me not fall (my Lord.)

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You ſhall not Florimell:
Mark how I'll work your peace, and how I honour ye.
Who waits there? come all in.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your pleaſure Sir.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Who dare ſay this ſweet beauty is not heavenly?
This virgin, the moſt pure, the moſt untainted,
The holieſt thing?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We know it (my dear Lord)
We are her ſlaves: and that proud impudence
That dares diſparage her, this ſword (my Lord.)

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: They are raſcals, baſe, the ſons of common women
That wrong this vertue, or dare owne a thought
But fair and honourable of her: when we ſlight her,
Hang us, or cut's in pieces: let's tug i'th' Gallies.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Brand us for villains.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why ſure I dream: theſe are all Saints.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Go, and live all her ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We are proud to do it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: What think ye now? am not I able Florimell
Yet to preſerve ye?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am bound to your Lordſhip,
Ye are all honour, and good my Lord but grant me
Untill to morrow leave to weigh my Fortunes,
I'll give you a free anſwer, perhaps a pleaſing,
Indeed I'll do the beſt I can to ſatisfie ye.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.p: Take your good time, this kiſſe, till then farewell, Sweet. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By all means diſcharge your follower.
