sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If we can get him off: Sirrha Buſtofa.
Thou muſt needs run back.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: But I muſt not unleſſe you ſend
A Bier, or a Lictor at my back, I do not uſe to run
From my friends.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, go will ſerve turne: I have forgot.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: What Sir,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: See if I can think on't now.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I know what 'tis now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A Piſtolet of that.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Done, you have forgot a device to ſend me away,
You are going a ſmocking perhaps.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: His owne, due, due i'faith Antonio,
The Piſtolet's his owne.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I confeſſe it,
There 'tis: now if you could afford out of it
A reaſonable excuſe to mine Uncle.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Yes, I can:
But an excuſe will not ſerve your turn: it muſt be a lie,
A full lie, 'twill do no good elſe: if you'll go to
The price of that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is a lie dearer then an excuſe?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Oh, treble; this is the price of an excuſe: but a lye is two more:
Look how many foyles go to a fair fall, ſo many excuſes to
A full lye, and leſſe cannot ſerve your turn, let any Tailor
I'th' Towne make it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wie, 'tis reaſonable, give him his price:
Let it be large enough now.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I'll warrant you, cover him all over.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would have proof of one now.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: What? ſcale my invention before hand? you ſhall pardon
Me for that: well, I'll commend you to your Uncle, and
Tell him you'll be at home at ſupper with him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By no means, I cannot come to night (man)

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I know that too, you do not know a lye when you ſee it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Remember it muſt ſtretch for all night.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: I ſhall want ſtuffe, I doubt 'twill come to the other Piſtolet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, lay out, you ſhall be no loſer Sir.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: It muſt be faced, you know, there will be a yard of diſſimulation
At leaſt (City-meaſure) and cut upon an untroth or two: Lyned
With Fables, that muſt needs be, cold weather's coming, if it had
A galloon of hypocriſie, 't would do well: and hooked
Together with a couple of conceits,
That's neceſſity; well, I'll bring in my
Bill: I'll warrant you as fair a lye by that time I have done
With it, as any gentleman i'th' Town can ſwear too: if he
Would betray his Lord and Maſter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So, ſo, this neceſſary trouble's over.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I would you had bought an excuſe of him
Before he went: you'll want one for Iſmenia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tuſh, there needs none, there's no ſuſpition yet,
And I'll be arm'd before the next encounter,
In a faſt tye with my fair Iſabel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, you'll find your errand is before you now.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Oh Gentlemen, look to your ſelves, ye are
Men of another world elſe: your enemies are upon you;
The old houſe of the Bellides will fall upon your heads:
Signior Liſauro.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: And Don what call you him? he's a Gentleman:
Yet he has but a Yeomans name,
Don Tarſo, Tarſo, and a dozen at their heels.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Liſauro, Tarſo, nor a dozen more
Shall fright me from my ground, nor ſhun my path,
Let'em come on in their ableſt fury.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis worthily reſolved: I'll ſtand by you Sir,
This way, I am thy true friend.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I'll be gone Sir, that one may live to tell what's become of you.
Put up, put up, will you never learn to know a lye
From an Eſop's fables? there's a taſte for you now. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Look Sir, what time of day is it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know not, my eies go falſe, I dare not truſt'em now,
I prethee tell me (Martin) if thou canſt,
Is that Iſmenia, or Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is the Lady, forget not Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If this face may be borrowed and lent out,
If it can ſhift ſhoulders, and take other tyres,
So, 'tis mine where ere I find it

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Be ſudden: Exit Aminta.
I cannot hold out long.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Beleeve't ſhe frowns.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it come, ſhe cannot frown me off on't:
How prettily it wooes me to come neerer?
How do you (Lady) ſince yeſterdaies pains?
Were you not weary? of my faith.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I think you were.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What Lady?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Weary of your faith, 'tis a burthen
That men faint under, though they bear little of it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So, this is to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You came home
In a fair hour I hope? Enter Aminta.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: From whence Sir?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Sir, there's a Gentlewoman without deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They were pretty homely toyes: but your preſence
Made them illuſtrious.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: My Coſen ſpeaks to you.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A Gentlewoman Sir, Iſabella
She names her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So, ſo, it hits finely now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Name your ſelf how you pleaſe: ſpeak what you pleaſe,
I'll hear you cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: You are not well,
Requeſt her in: ſhe may have more acquaintance
With his paſſions, and better cure for'em.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: She's nice in that (Madam) poor ſoul it ſeems
She's fearfull of your diſpleaſure.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I'll quit her
From that preſently, and bring her in my ſelf. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How careleſly do you behave your ſelf?
When you ſhould call all your beſt faculties
To councell in you: how will you anſwer
The breach you made with fair Iſmenia?
Have you forgot the retrograde vow you took
With her, that now is come in evidence?
You'll die upon your ſhame, you need no more
Enemies of the houſe, but the Lady now:
You ſhall have your diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give me that face,
And I am ſatisfied upon whoſe ſhoulders
So ere it growes: Juno deliver us
Out of this amazement: Beſeech you Goddeſſe
Tell us of our friends, how dos Iſmenia?
And how does Iſabella? both in good health
I hope, as you your ſelf are.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I am at fartheſt
In my counterfeit: my Antonio
I have ma●ter againſt you may need pardon,
As I muſt crave of you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Obſerve you Sir,
What evidence is come againſt me? what think you
The Hydra-headed Jury will ſay to't?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis I am foold,
My hopes are pour'd into the bottomles tube,
Tis labour for the houſe of Bellides:
I muſt not ſeem ſo yet: but in ſooth (Lady)
Did you imagine your changeable face
Hid you from me? by this hand I knew you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I went by the face: and by theſe eies I
Might have been deceived.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: You might indeed (Antonio)
For this Gentleman did vow to Iſabella,
That he it was that lov'd Iſmenia,
And not Antonio?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good, and was not that
A manifeſt confeſſion that I knew you?
I elſe had been unjuſt unto my friend:
Twas well remembred, there I found you out
And ſpeak your conſcience now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But did he ſo proteſt?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Yes, I vow to you, had Antonio
Wedded Iſabella, Iſmenia
Had not been loſt, there had been her lover.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why much good do you friend, take her to you:
I crave but one, here have I my wiſh full,
I am glad we ſhall be ſo neer Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take both Sir, Juno to boote: three parts in one,
S. Hilarie bleſſe you, now oportunitie
Beware to meet with falſhood, if thou canſt
Shun it, my friends faith's turning from him.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Might I not juſtly accuſe Antonio
For a love-wanderer? you know no other
But me, for another, and confeſſe troth now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here was my guide, where ere I find this face,
I am a Lover, marry, I muſt not miſſe
This freckle then, I have the number of 'em,
Nor this dimple: not a ſilk from this brow,
I carry the full Idea ever with me;
If Nature can ſo punctually paralel,
I may be cozened.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Well, all this is even:
But now, to perfect all, our love muſt now
Come to our Enemies hands, where neither part
Will ever give conſent to't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Moſt certain:
For which reaſon it muſt not be put to'em:
Have we not prevention in our owne hands.
Shall I walk by the tree? deſire the fruit,
Yet be ſo nice to pull till I ask leave
Of the churliſh Gardner, that will deny me?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: O Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis manners to fall to
When grace is ſaid.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: That holy act 's to come.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You may ope an oyſter or two before grace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are there not double vows, as valuable
And as well ſpoke as any Frier utters?
Heaven has heard all.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Yes: but ſtayes the bleſſing,
Till all dues be done: heaven is not ſerv'd by halfs.
Wee ſhall have ne'r a fathers bleſſing here,
Let us not loſe the better, from above.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You take up weapons of unequal force,
It ſhows you cowardly: heark in your ear.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Have I loſt all imployment? Would this proffer
Had been made to me, though I had paid it
With a reaſonable pennance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have I paſt
All thy fore-lock (Time)? I'll ſtretch a long arm
But I'll catch hold again: Doe but look back
Over thy ſhoulder, and have a pull at thee.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: I hear you (Sir) nor can I hear too much
While you ſpeak well: You know th' accuſtom'd place
Of our night parley: if you can aſcend,
The window ſhall receive you. You may finde there
A corrupted Church-man to bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would meet no other man.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Aminta, you hear this.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: With joy (Madam) 'cauſe it pleaſes you.
It may be mine own caſe another time:
Now you go the right way: ask the Banes out,
Put it paſt father, or friends, to forbid it,
And then you're ſure. Sir, your Hymen Taper
I'll light up for you: the window ſhall ſhow you
The way to Sestos.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll venture drowning.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The Simile holds not; 'tis hanging rather.
You muſt aſcend your Caſtle by a ladder;
To the foot I'll bring you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Leave mee to climb it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If I do turn you off?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Till night fare-well:
Then better.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Beſt it ſhould be;
But peeviſh hatred keeps back that degree. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I never look'd ſo ſmooth as now I purpoſe:
And then beware: Knave is at worſt of knave
When he ſmiles beſt, and the moſt ſeems to ſave. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My mind's unquiet; while Antonio
My Nephew's abroad, my heart is not at home,
Only my fears ſtay with me; bad company;
But I cannot ſhift 'em off. This hatred
Betwixt the Houſe of Bellides and us,
Is not fair war: 'tis civill, but uncivill.
We are neer neighbours, were of love as neer,
Till a croſſe miſconſtruction ('twas no more
In conſcience) put us ſo far aſunder:
I would 'twere reconcil'd; it has laſted
Too many Sun-ſets, if grace might moderate:
Man ſhould not loſe ſo many dayes of peace
To ſatisfie the anger of one minute.
I could repent it heartily. I ſent
The knave to attend my Antonio too, Enter Buſtofa.
Yet he rerurns no comfort to me neither.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: No: I muſt not.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Hah; hee's come.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I muſt not: 'twill breake his heart to hear it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How? there's bad tidings: I muſt obſcure & hear it;
He will not tell mee for breaking of my heart,
'Tis half ſplit already.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: I have ſpi'd him: Now to knock down a Don with a lie, a ſilly harmleſſe lie; 'twill be valiantly done, and nobly perhaps.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I cannot hear him now.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Oh the bloody dayes that wee live in; the envi|ous, malitious, deadly dayes that we draw breath in!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now I hear too loud.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: The children that never ſhall be born may rue it; for men that are ſlain now might have liv'd to have got children, that might have curſ'd their fathers.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, my poſterity is ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Oh ſweet Antonio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh deer Antonio.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Yet it was nobly done of both parts: When hee and Liſauro met,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, death has parted 'em.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Welcome my mortall foe (ſayes one), Welcome my deadly enemy (ſayes th'other:) off go their doublets, they in their ſhirts, and their ſwords ſtark naked; here lies Antonio, here lies Liſauro: hee comes upon him with an Embroccado, that hee puts by with a puncta reverſa; Liſauro recoils mee two paces and ſome ſix inches back, takes his career, and then, oh.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Runs Antonio quite thorow,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh villain.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Quite thorow between the arme and the body: ſo yet he had no hurt at that bout.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Goodneſſe be praiſed.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: But then, at next encounter, he fetches me up Li|ſauro; Liſauro makes out a Long at him, which he think|ing to be a Paſſado, Antonio's foot ſlipping: down: oh down.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O now thou art loſt.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Oh, but the quality of the thing: both Gentle|men, both Spaniſh Chriſtians, yet one man to ſhed

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Say his enemies blood.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: His hair may come by divers caſualties, though he never go into the field with his foe: but a man to loſe nine ounces and two drams of blood at one wound, thir|teen and a ſcruple at another, and to live till he die in cold blood: yet the Surgeon (that cur'd him) ſaid, if Pia-mater had not been periſh'd, he had bin a lives man til this day.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: There hee concludes he is gone.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: But all this is nothing: now I come to the point.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I the point, that's deadly: the ancient blow
Over the buckler ne'r went half ſo deep.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p:
Yet pitie bids mee keep in my charitie: for mee to pull an old mans ears from his head with telling of a Tale: oh fowle Tale! No, be ſilent Tale. Furthermore, there is the charge of Buriall; every one will cry Blacks, Blacks, that had but the leaſt finger dipt in his blood, though ten degrees remov'd when 'twas done. Moreover,
the Surgeon (that made an end of him) will be paid: Su|gar-plums and ſweet breads; yet I ſay, the man may reco|ver again, and die in his bed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What motley ſtuffe is this? Sirrha, ſpeak truth
What hath befallen my deer Antonio?
Reſtrain your pity in concealing it;
Tell mee the danger full; take off your care
Of my receiving it: kill me that way,
I'll forgive my death: what thou keepſt back from truth
Thou ſhalt ſpeak in pain; doe not look to find
A limb in his right place, a bone unbroke,
Nor ſo much fleſh unbroil'd of all that mountain
As a worm might ſup on; diſpatch, or be diſpatch'd.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Alas Sir, I know nothing, but that Anton. is a man of Gods making to this hour, 'tis not two ſince I left him ſo.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Where didſt thou leave him?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: In the ſame clothes he had on when he went from you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Does he live?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I ſaw him drink.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Is he not wounded?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: He may have a cut i'th' leg by this time; for Don Martin and he were at whole ſlaſhes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Met he not with Liſauro?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I doe not know her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Her? Liſauro is a man, as he is.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I ſaw ne'r a man like him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Didſt thou not diſcourſe a fight betwixt Ant. & Liſ.?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: I to my ſelf; I hope a man may give himſelf the lie if it pleaſe him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Didſt thou lie then?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: As ſure as you live now.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I live the happier by it: when will he return?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: That he ſent me to tel you, within theſe ten daies at fartheſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ten daies? he's not wont to be abſent two.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Nor I think he wil not: he ſaid he would be at home to morrow; but I love to ſpeak within my compaſſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You ſhall ſpeak within mine Sir, now. Within there:
Take this fellow into cuſtodie, keep him ſafe
I charge you.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Safe? do you hear? take notice what plight you find me in, if there want but a collop or a ſteak o'me, look to't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If my nephew return not in his health to morrow,
Thou goeſt to th' Rack.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Let me go to th' manger firſt; I had rather eat oats then hay. Exeunt. Enter Bellides with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: By your leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: For ought I know yet, you are welcom Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Read that, and tell me ſo: or if thy ſpectacles be not eaſie,
Keep thy noſe unſadled, and ope thine ears;
I can ſpeak thee the contents, I made 'em;
'Tis a challenge, a fair one, I'll maintain 't:
I ſcorn to hire my Second to deliver 't,
I bring 't my ſelf: Doſt know me, Julio?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes: Is not thine hair on end now?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Somwhat amaz'd at thy raſh hardines;
How durſt thou come ſo neer thine enemie?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Durſt?
I dare come neerer: thou'rt a fool, Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Take it home to thee with a knave to boot.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Knave to thy teeth again: and all that's quit:
Give me not a fool more then I give thee,
Or if thou doſt, look to hear on't again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What an encounter's this?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A noble one:
My hand is to my words, thou haſt it there,
There I do challenge thee, if thou dar'ſt be,
Good friends with me; or I'll proclaim thee coward.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be friends with thee?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll ſhew thee reaſons for't:
A pair of old coxcombs (now wee go together)
Such as ſhould ſtand examples of diſcretion,
The rules of Grammar to unwilling youth
To take out leſſons by; we that ſhould check
And quench the raging fire in others bloods,
We ſtrike the battell to deſtruction?
Read 'em the black art? and make 'em beleeve
It is divinitie? Heathens, are we not?
Speak thy conſcience, how haſt thou ſlept this month,
Since this Fiend haunted us?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sure, ſome good Angell
Was with us both laſt night: ſpeak thou truth now,
Was it not laſt nights motion?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Doſt not think
I would not lay hold of it at firſt proffer?
Should I ne'r ſleep again?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Take not all from me;
I'll tell the doctrine of my viſion.
Say that Antonio (beſt of thy blood)
Or any one, the leaſt allyed to thee,
Should be the prey unto Liſauro's ſword,
Or any of the houſe of Bellides?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine was the juſt inverſion: on, on.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How would thine eys have emptied thee in ſorrow,
And left the condiment of Nature drie?
Thy hands have turn'd rebellious to the balls,
And broke the glaſſes, with thine own curſes
Have torn thy ſoul, left thee a Statue
To propagate thy next poſterity.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, and thou cauſer? ſo it ſaid to me,
They fight but your miſchiefs: the yong men were friends,
As is the life and blood coagulate
And curded in one body; but this is yours,
An inheritance that you have gatherd for 'em,
A Legacie of blood, to kill each other
Throughout your Generations. Was't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Word for word.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nay, I can go farther yet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis far enough; Let us attone it here.
And in a reconciled circle fold
Our friendſhip new again.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The ſigne's in Gemini,
An auſpicious houſe, 't has joyn'd both ours again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You cannot proclaim me coward now, Don Bellides

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No: thou 'rt a valiant fellow: ſo am I:
I'll fight with thee at this hug, to the laſt leg
I have to ſtand on, or breath or life left.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This is the ſalt unto humanity,
And keeps it ſweet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Love! oh life ſtinks without it.
I can tell you news.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Good has long been wanting.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I do ſuſpect, and I have ſome proof on't,
(So far as a Love Epiſtle comes to)
That Antonio (your nephew) and my daughter
Iſmenia are very good friends before us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That were a double wall about our houſes,
Which I could wiſh were builded.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I had it
From Antonio's Intimate, Don Martin:
And yet (me thought) it was no friendly part
To ſhow it me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Perhaps 't was his conſent:
Lovers have policies as well as Stateſmen:
They look not alwaies at the mark they aime at.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Wee'll take up cudgels, and have one bowt with'em,
They ſhall know nothing of this union:
And till they find themſelves moſt deſperate,
Succour ſhall never ſee'em.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll take your part Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It grows late; there's a happy day paſt us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The example I hope to all behind it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Stand fair, light of Love, which epithite and place
Adds to thee honour, to me it would be ſhame,
We muſt be weight in love, no grain too light;
Thou art the Land-mark, but if love be blind,
(As many that can ſee have ſo reported)
What benefit canſt thou be to his darkneſſe?
Love is a Jewel (ſome ſay) ineſtimable,
But hung at the eare, deprives our owne ſight,
And ſo it ſhines to others, not our ſelves.
I ſpeak my skill, I have onely heard on't,
But I could wiſh a neerer document,
Alas, the ignorant deſire to know:
Some ſay Love's but a toy, and with a but.
Now me thinks I ſhould love it ne'r the worſe,
A toy is harmeleſſe ſure, and may be plaid with,
It ſeldom goes without his adjunct, pretty,
A pretty toy we ſay, 'tis meeter to joy too.
Well, here may be a mad night yet for all this,
Here's a Prieſt ready, and a Lady ready:
A chamber ready, and a bed ready,
'Tis then but making unready, and that's ſoone done:
My Lady is my Coſen; I, my ſelf,
Which is neereſt then? My deſires are mine,
Say they be hers too, is't a hanging matter?
It may be ventur'd in a worſer cauſe,
I muſt go queſtion with my conſcience:
I have the word; Centinel, do thou ſtand,
Thou ſhalt not need to call, I'll he at hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are we not dog'd behind us, thinkſt thou friend?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I heard not one bark, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There are that bite
And bark not (man) me-thought I ſpy'd two fellows
That through two ſtreets together walk'd aloof,
And wore their eies ſuſpiciouſly upon us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your Jealouſie, nothing elſe; or ſuch perhaps
As are afraid as much of us, who knows
But about the like buſines? but for your fears ſake
I'll adviſe and entreat one curteſie.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's that friend?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will not be denyed, Sir,
Change your upper garments with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It needs not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I think ſo too, but I will have it ſo,
If you dare truſt me with the better Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If there ſhould be danger towards,
There will be the main mark I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here thou tak'ſt from me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tuſh, the General
Muſt be ſafe, how ere the Battel goes:
See you the Beacon yonder?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, we are neer ſhore.

div.stage: Enter 2. Gentlemen with weapons drawn, they ſet upon Mar|tin: Antonio purſues them out in reſcue of Martin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, Land, land, you muſt clamber by the cliffe,
Here are no ſtaires to riſe by.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I, are you there? fight and Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Aminta above, and Martin return'd again, aſcends.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes Iſmenia.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Thine owne.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Quench the light, thine eies are guides illuſtrious.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Tis neceſſary. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your legs have ſav'd your lives, who ere you are,
Friend. Martin? where art thou? not hurt I hope:
Sure I was fartheſt in the purſuit of 'em:
My pleaſures are forgotten through my fears:
The lights extinct, it was diſcreetly done:
They could not but have notice of the broile,
And fearing that might call up company,
Have carefully prevented, and cloſed up:
I do commend the heed; oh, but my friend,
I fear his hurt: friend? friend? it cannot be
So mortal, that I ſhould loſe thee quite, friend?
A groan, any thing that may diſcover thee:
Thou art not ſunk ſo far, but I might hear thee:
I'll lay mine ear as low as thou canſt fall:
Friend, Don Martin, I muſt anſwer for thee,
'Twas in my cauſe thou fell'ſt, if thou beeſt downe,
Such dangers ſtand betwixt us and our joyes,
That ſhould we forethink ere we undertake,
Wee'ld ſit at home, and ſave. What a night's here?
Purpos'd for ſo much joy, and now diſpos'd
To ſo much wretchednes? I ſhall not reſt in't:
If I had all my pleaſures there within,
I ſhould not entertain'em with a ſmile.
Good night to you: Mine will be black and ſad,
A friend cannot, a woman may be bad. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: O thou falſe,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Do your daringſt, he's mine owne,
Soul and body mine, church and chamber mine,
Totally mine.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Darſt thou face thy falſhood?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Shall I not give a welcom to my wiſhes
Come home ſo ſweetly: farewell your company
Till you be calmer woman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Oh what a heap
Of miſery has one night brought with it. Ent. Ant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is he? do you turn your ſhame from me?
You'r a blind Adultreſſe, you know you are.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: How's that Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Till I have vengeance,
Your ſin's not pardonable: I'll have him,
If hell hide him not: y'have had your laſt of him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: What did he ſpeak? I underſtood him not,
He calld me a foul name, it was not mine,
He took me for another ſure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hah? are you there?
Where's your ſweet heart? I have found you Traytor
To my houſe: wilt league with mine enemie?
You'll ſhed his blood, you'll ſay: hah? will you ſo?
And fight with your heels upwards? No Minion,
I have a husband for you, ſince y'are ſo ranck,
And ſuch a husband as thou ſhalt like him,
Whether thou wilt or no: Antonio?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: It thunders with the ſtorm now.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And to night
I'll have it diſpatch'd: I'll make it ſure, I,
By to morrow this time thy Maiden-head
Shall not be worth a Chicken, if it were
Knockt at an out-cry: go, I'll ha'ye before me:
Shough, ſhough, up to your coop, peay Hen.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Then I'll try my wings. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I, are you good at that? ſtop, ſtop thief, ſtop there. Exit.

div.head: Scaena ſecunda.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now having leiſure, and a happy wind,
Thou maiſt at pleaſure cauſe the ſtones to grind,
Sayles ſpread, and grift here ready to be ground.
Fie, ſtand not idely, but let the Mill go round.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Why doſt thou ſing and dance thus? why ſo merry?
Why doſt thou look ſo wantonly upon me?
And kiſſe my hands?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If I were high enough,
I would kiſſe your lips too.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Do, this is ſome kindnes,
This taſtes of willingneſſe, nay, you may kiſſe
Still, but why o'th' ſudden now does the fitt take ye,
Unoffered, or uncompell'd? why theſe ſweet curteſies?
Even now you would have bluſh'd to death to kiſſe thus:
Prethee let me be prepar'd to meet thy kindnes,
I ſhall be unfurniſh'd elſe to hold thee play, wench:
Stay now a little, and delay your bleſſings:
If this be love, me-thinks it is too violent:
If you repent you of your ſtrictneſſe to me,
It is ſo ſudden, it wants circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Fy, how dull?

body.head: 2. Song.
body.l: How long ſhall I pine for love?
how long ſhall I ſue in vaine?
How long like the Turtle-Dove
ſhall I heavily thus complain?
Shall the ſayles of my love ſtand ſtill?
Shall the griſts of my hopes be unground?
Oh fie, oh fie, oh fie,
let the Mill, let the Mill go round.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Prethee be calme a little,
Thou mak'ſt me wonder, thou that wert ſo ſtrange,
And read ſuch pious rules to my behaviour
But yeſternight: thou that wert made of modeſtie,
Shouldſt in a few ſhort minutes turn thus deſperate.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You are too cold.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I do confeſſe I freeze now,
I am another thing all over me:
It is my part to wooe, not to be courted:
Unfold this Riddle, 'tis to me a wonder,
That now o'th' inſtant ere I can expect,
Ere I can turn my thoughts, and think upon
A ſeparation of your honeſt carriage
From the deſires of youth, thus wantonly,
Thus beyond expectation.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will tell ye,
And tell ye ſeriouſly, why I appear thus,
To hold ye no more ignorant and blinded,
I have no modeſtie, I am truly wanton:
I am that you look for Sir; now come up roundly:
If my ſtrict face and counterfeited ſtaledneſſe
Could have won on ye, I had caught ye that way,
And you ſhould ne'r have come to have known who hurt ye.
Prethee (ſweet Count) be more familiar with me.
How ever we are open in our natures,
And apt to more deſires then you dare meet with,
Yet we affect to lay the gloſſe of good on 't:
I ſaw you toucht not at the baite of chaſtity,
And that it grew diſtaſtefull to pour palate
To appear ſo holy, therefore I take my true ſhape:
Is your bed ready Sir? you ſhall quickly find me.

body.head: 3. Song.
body.l: On the bed Ile throw thee, throw thee downe;
Down being laid, ſhall we be afraid
to try the rights that belong to love?
No, no, there Ile wooe thee with a Crown,
crown our deſires, kindle the fires,
when love requires we ſhould wanton prove:
We'll kiſſe, we'll ſport, we'll laugh, we'll play,
If thou com'ſt ſhort, for thee Ile ſtay,
If thou unskilfull art the ground,
Ile kindly teach, we'll have the Mill go round.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Are ye no maid?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas (my Lord) no certain:
I am ſorry you are ſo innocent to think ſo,
Is this an age for ſilly maids to thrive in?
It is ſo long too ſince I loſt it Sir,
That I have no belief I ever was one:
What ſhould you do with maiden-heads? you hate'em,
They are peeviſh pettiſh things, that hold no game up,
No pleaſure neither, they are ſport for Surgeons:
I'll warrant you I'll fit you beyond Maiden-head:
A fair and eaſie way men travel right in,
And with delight, diſcourſe, and twenty pleaſures,
They enjoy their journey; mad men creep through hedges.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I am metamorphoſed: why do you appeare,
I conjure ye, beyond belief thus wanton?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Becauſe I would give ye
Pleaſure beyond belief.

body.head: 4. Song.
body.l: Think me ſtill in my Fathers Mill,
where I have oft been found-a
Thrown on my back, on a well-fill'd ſack,
while the Mill has ſtill gone round-a:
Prethee ſirrha try thy skill,
and again let the mill go round-a.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Then you have traded?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Traded? how ſhould I know elſe how to live Sir,
And how to ſatisfie ſuch Lords as you are,
Our beſt gueſts, and our richeſt?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: How I ſhake now?
You take no baſe men?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Any that will offer,
All manner of men, and all Religions Sir,
We touch at in our time: all States and Ages,
We exempt none.

body.head: 5. Song.
body.l: The young one, the old one, the fearful, the bold one,
the lame one, though nere ſo unſound,
The Jew or the Turk, have leave for to work,
the whileſt that the Mill goes round,

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You are a common thing then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No matter ſince you have your private pleaſure,
And have it by an Artiſt excellent,
Whether I am thus, or thus, your men can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: My men? Defend me, how I freeze together,
And am on ice? do I bite at ſuch an Orange
After my men? I am preferr'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why ſtay ye?
Why do we talk my Lord, and loſe our time?
Pleaſure was made for lips, and ſweet embraces,
Let Lawyers uſe their tongues: pardon me Modeſtie,
This deſperate way muſt help, or I am miſerable.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: She turns, and wipes her face, ſhe weeps for certain,
Some new way now, ſhe cannot be thus beaſtly,
She is too excellent fair to be thus impudent:
She knows the elements of common looſeneſſe,
The art of lewdneſſe: that, that, that, how now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The King (and't pleaſe your Lordſhip) is alighted Cloſe at the gate.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: The King?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And calls for ye Sir.
Means to break-faſt here too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Then I am happy.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Stolne ſo ſuddenly? go lock her up,
Lock her up where the Courtiers may not ſee her,
Lock her up cloſely, ſirrha, in my cloſet.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will (my Lord) what does ſhe yeeld yet? Exit.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Peace:
She is either a damnd divel, or an Angel,
No noiſe (upon your life Dame) but all ſilence.

div.stage: Enter King, Lords, Vertigo, Liſauro, Terſo.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Your Majeſty he●ps too much honour on me,
With ſuch delight to view each ſeveral corner
Of a rude pile: there's no proportion in't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Me-thinks 'tis hanſom, and the rooms along
Are neat, and well contriv'd: the Gallery
Stands pleaſantly and ſweet: what rooms are theſe?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: They are ſluttiſh ones.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, I muſt ſee.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Pray ye do Sir,
They are lodging-chambers over a homely garden.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fit ſtill, and hanſom; very well: and thoſe?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.p: Thoſe lead to the other ſide o'th' houſe, and't like ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let me ſee thoſe.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Ye may, the dores are open.
What ſhould this view mean? I am half ſuſpicious.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This little Room?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Tis mean: a place for traſh Sir,
For rubbiſh of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I would ſee this too:
I will ſee all.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I beſeech your Majeſty,
The ſavour of it, and the courſe appearance.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis not ſo bad, you would not offend your houſe with it,
Come, let me ſee.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Faith Sir,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'faith I will ſee.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: My Groom has the key Sir, and 'tis ten to one

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But I will ſee it: force the lock (my Lords)
There be ſmithes enough to mend it: I perceive
You keep ſome rare things here, you would not ſhow Sir.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Here's a fair maid indeed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By my faith is ſhe
A hanſom girle: come forward, do not fear wench.
I marry, here's a treaſure worth concealing:
Call in the Miller.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Then I am diſcovered.
I confeſſe all before the Miller comes Sir,
'Twas but intention, from all act I am cleer yet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, and 't pleaſe your Highneſſe.
This is the ſhape of her, for her ſubſtance Sir,
Whether ſhe be now honourable or diſhonourable:
Whether ſhe be a white-roſe, or a canker, is the queſtion:
I thank my Lord, he made bold with my Philly,
If ſhe be for your pace, you had beſt preſerve her Sir,
She is tender mouthed, let her be broken hanſomly.
Maid, were you ſtolne?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I went not willingly,
And 't pleaſe your Grace, I was never bred ſo boldly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How has he us'd ye?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yet Sir, very nobly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be ſure ye tell truth, and be ſure (my Lord)
You have not wrongd her: if ye have, I tell ye
You have loſt me, and your ſelf too: ſpeak again (wench)

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He has not wrong'd me, Sir; I am yet a maid:
By all that's white and innocent, I am Sir,
Onely I ſufferd under ſtrong temptations
The heat of youth; but heaven deliverd me.
My Lord, I am no whore, for all I faign'd it,
And faign'd it cunningly, and made ye loath me:
'Twas time to out-do you: I had been robd elſe,
I had been miſerable, but I forgive ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What recompence for this?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: A great one Sir,
Firſt a repentance, and a hearty one.
Forgive me Sweet.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I do my Lord.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I thank ye;
The next take this, and theſe: all I have Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No good my Lord, theſe often corrupt maidens:
I dare not touch at theſe; they are lime for Virgins;
But if you'll give me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Any thing in my power.
Or in my purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Take heed (noble Sir)
You'll make me a bold asker.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Aske me freely.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ask you? I do ask you, and I deſerve ye,
I have kept ye from a crying ſin would damne ye
To Men and Time: I have preſerv'd your credit,
That would have died to all poſterity:
Curſes of maids ſhall never now afflict ye,
Nor Parents bitter tears make your name barren:
If he deſerves well that redeems his Countrey,
And as a Patriot be remembred nobly,
Nay, ſet the higheſt: may not I be worthy
To be your friend, that have preſervd your honor?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You are, and thus I take ye: thus I ſeal ye
Mine owne, and onely mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Count, ſhe deſerves ye,
And let it be my happines to give ye,
I have given a vertuous maid, now I dare ſay it,
'Tis more then blood; I'll pay her portion Sir,
And't ſhall be worthy you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I'll ſell my Mill,
I'll pay ſome too: I'll pay the Fidlers,
And we'll have all i' th' Country at this wedding,
Pray let me give her too, here my Lord take her,
Take her with all my heart, and kiſſe her freely,
Would I could give you all this hand has ſtolne too,
In portion with her, 'twould make her a little whiter.
The wind blows fair now, get me a young Miller.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Shee muſt have new clothes.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes marry muſt ſhe.
If't pleaſe ye (Madam) let me ſee the ſtate of you body.
I'll fit you inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Art not thou gone yet?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And 't pleaſe your Grace, a gown, a handſome gown now,
An orient gown.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, take thy pleaſure of her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Of cloth of Tiſſew I can fit ye (Madam)
My Lords, ſtand out o'th' light, a curious body,
The neateſt body in Spain this day: w^t^h embroidred flowrs,
A clinquant Petticoat of ſome rich ſtuffe,
To catch the eye: I have a thouſand faſhions.
O ſleeve, O ſleeve: I'll ſtudy all night (Madam)
To magnifie your ſleeve.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Do, ſuperſtitious Tailor,
When yee have more time.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Make me no more then woman,
And I am thine.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Sir, haply my Wardrobe with your help
May fit her inſtantly: will you try her?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If I fit her not, your Wardrobe cannot.
But if the faſhion be not there, you marre her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is my offence ſo great, ere I be convict,
To be torn with Raſcals? If it be Law,
Let 'm be wild horſes, rather then theſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: This is a man ſuſpected of murder, if it pleaſe your Grace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It pleaſes me not (friend). But who ſuſpects him?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: We that are your Highnes extraordinary officers,
We that have taken our oaths to maintain you in peace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Twill be a great charge to you.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: 'Tis a great charge indeed; but then we call our neighbours to help us. This Gentleman and another were fallen out (yet that's more then I am able to ſay, for I heard no words between 'em, but what their weapons ſpoke, Claſh, and Clatter) which we ſeeing, came with our Bils of government, and firſt knock'd down their weapons, and then the men.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And this you did to keep the peace?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Yes, and 't like your Grace, we knock'd 'em down to keep the peace: this we laid hold on, the other we ſet in the ſtocks. That I could do by mine own power, with|out your Majeſtie. Enter Aminta.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I am a Shoo-maker by my Trade.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Oh my husband!
Why ſtands my husband as a man endanger'd?
Reſtore him me, as you are mercifull,
I'll anſwer for him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What woman's this? what husband? hold thy bawling,
I know thee for no wife.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You married me laſt night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt: I neither was in Church nor houſe
Laſt night, nor ſaw I thee: a thing that was my friend,
I ſcorne to name now, was with Iſmenia,
Like a thief, and there he violated
A ſacred truſt. This thou maiſt know (Aminta).

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Are not you hee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No; nor a friend of his:
Would I had kill'd him: I hope I have.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: That was my husband (Royall Sir) that man,
That excellent man. Enter Bellides.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That villain, that theefe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Have I caught you Sir? well overtaken.
This is mine enemie: pardon (my Soveraigne).

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good charitie, to crave pardon for your enemie.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine own pardon (Sir) for my joyes rudeneſſe:
In what place better could I meet my foe,
And both of us ſo well provided too?
Hee with ſome black blood-thirſtie crime upon him,
That (ere the horſe-leech burſt) will ſuck him dry:
I with a ſecond accuſation,
Enough to break his neck, if need ſhould be,
And then to have even Juſtice ſelf to right us:
How ſhould I make my joyes a little civill,
They might not keep this noyſe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here is ſome hope.
Should the ax be dull, the halter's preparing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What's your accuſation, Sir? We have heard the former. Enter Julio.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine (My Lord)? a ſtrong one.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A falſe one, Sir.
At leaſt malicious: an evidence
Of hatred and deſpight: He would accuſe
My poor kinſman of that he never dream'd of,
Nor waking ſaw; the ſtealing of his daughter,
She whom, I know, he would not look upon.
Speak Antonio, Didſt thou ever ſee her?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I have ſeen her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ah ha, friend Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He might, but how? with an unheedfull eye,
An accidentall view, as men ſee multitudes
That the next day dare not preciſely ſay
They ſaw that face, or that amongſt 'm all,
Didſt thou ſo look on her?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Guilty, guilty:
His looks hang themſelves.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your patience (Gentleman).
I pray you tell me if I be in errour,
I may ſpeak often when I ſhould but hear:
This is ſome Show you would preſent us with,
And I do interrupt it: Pray you ſpeak,
(It ſeems no more) Is 't any thing but a Show?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My Lord, this Gentlewoman can ſhow you all,
So could my daughter too, if ſhee were here;
By this time they are both immodeſt enough:
Shee's fled me, and I accuſe this thief for't.
Don Martin, his own friend 's my teſtimony:
A practiſ'd night-work.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That Martin's the other
In your cuſtodie; he was forgotten:
Fetch him hither.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Wee'll bring the Stocks and all elſe, and't pleaſe your Grace. Enter Buſtofa and Iſmenia.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: That man's my husband certain, inſtead of this:
Both would have deceiv'd, and both beguil'd.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Soh hoh, Miller, Miller, look out Miller: is there nere a Miller amongſt you here, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Yes Sir, here is a Miller amongſt Gentlemen,
A Gentleman Miller.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: I ſhould not be far off then; there went but a pair of ſheers and a bodkin between us. Will you to work Miller? Here's a maid has a ſack full of newes for you, ſhall your ſtones walk? will you grind Miller?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This your ſon, Franio?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My ungratious, my diſobedient,
My unnaturall, my rebell ſon (my Lord).

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Fie, your hopper runs over, Miller.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This villain (of my own fleſh & blood) was acceſſary
To the ſtealing of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Oh mountain,
Shalt thou call a molehill a ſcab upon the face
Of the earth? Though a man be a thief, ſhall a Miller call
Him ſo? Oh egregious!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Remember Sirha, who you ſpeak before.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I ſpeak before a Miller,
A thief in grain; for he ſteals corn: He that ſteals
A wench, is a true man to him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Can you prove that? you may help another cauſe that was in pleading.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I'll prove it ſtrongly.
He that ſteals corn, ſteals the bread of the Cōmon-wealth;
He that ſteals a wench, ſteals but the fleſh.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And how is the bread ſtealing more criminall then the fleſh?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Hee that ſteals bread, ſteals that which is lawfull every day:
He that ſteals fleſh, ſteals nothing from the faſting day:
Ergo, To ſteal the bread is the arranter theft.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is to ſome purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Again, He that ſteals fleſh, ſteals for his own belly full:
He that ſteals bread, robs the guts of others:
Ergo, The arranter theef the bread-ſtealer.
sp.p: Again, He that ſteals fleſh, ſteals once, and gives over; yes, and often payes for it: the other ſteals every day, without ſatisfaction. To conclude, Bread-ſtealing is the more ca|pitall crime: for what he ſteals hee puts it in at the head: hee that ſteals fleſh (as the Dutch Author ſayes) puts it in at the foot, (the lower member.) Will you go as you are now, Miller?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How has this ſatisfied you, Don Bellides?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nothing (my Lord,) my cauſe is ſerious.
I claim a daughter from that loving theefe there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would I had her for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ah ha, Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How ſaid you (Antonio)? Wiſh you you had his daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With my ſoul I wiſh her; and my body
Shall periſh, but I'll enjoy my ſouls wiſh.
I would have ſlain my friend for his deceit,
But I do find his own deceit hath paid him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Will you vex my ſoul forth? no other choice
But where my hate is rooted? Come hither Girl,
Whoſe pretty maid art thou?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: The child of a poor man, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The better for it. With my Soveraigns leave,
I'll wed thee to this man, will hee, nill he.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pardon me, Sir, I'll be no Love enforcer:
I uſe no power of mine unto thoſe ends.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Wilt thou have him?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Not unleſſe he love me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do love thee: Farewell all other Beauties:
I ſettle here: You are Iſmenia.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: The ſame I was: better nor worſe (Antonio)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I ſhall have your conſent here, I'm ſure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: With all my heart, Sir. Nay, if you accept it,
I'll do this kindneſſe to mine enemie,
And give her as a Father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shee'll thank you as a Daughter.
Will you not, Iſmenia?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How? Iſmenia?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.l: Your daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: B●l
sp.l: ſſiPoble? Away you feeble witted things,
You thought you had caught the old ones: You wade, you wade
In ſhallow fords: Wee can ſwim, we: look here,
We made the match: we are all friends, good friends;
Thin, thin: why the fool knew all this, this fool.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Keep that to your ſelf, Sir; What I knew I knew: This Sack is a witneſſe. Miller, this is not for your thum|ming. Here's gold lace: you may ſee her in her holliday clothes if you will; I was her ward-robe-man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You beguil'd me well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Did you ſpeak to me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It might ſeem to you (Martin), your conſcience
Has quick ears.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My ſight was a little dim i'th' dark, indeed,
So was my feeling cozen'd; yet I'm content:
I am the better underſtander now,
I know my wife wants nothing of a woman;
There y'are my Junior.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are not hurt?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not ſhrewdly hurt; I have good fleſh to heal, you ſee,
Good round fleſh: theſe cherries wil be worth chopping,
Crack ſtones and all; I ſhould not give much to boot
To ride in your new, and you in my old ones now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You miſtake the weapon: are you not hurt?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A little ſcratch: but I ſhal claw it off wel enough.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: I can no longer own what is not mine
With a free conſcience: My Liege, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For what? Who knows this woman?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I beſt (my Lord),
I have been acquainted with her theſe fortie Summers,
And as many Winters, were it Spring agen;
She's like the Gout, I can get no cure for her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh, your wife, Franio?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis oh my wife indeed (my Lord,)
A painfull ſtitch to my ſide; would it were pick'd out.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well Sir, your ſilence.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Wil you be older and older every day then other? the longer you live the older ſtill? Muſt his Majeſtie com|mand your ſilence ere you'l hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your reprehenſion runs into the ſame fault:
Pray Sir, will you be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I have told him of this before now (my Liege) but
Age will have his courſe, and his weakneſſes,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good Sir, your forbearance.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: And his frailties, and his follies (as I may ſay) that cannot hold his tongue ere he be bidden.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why Sirha?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: But I beleeve your Majeſtie will not be long trou|bled with him: I hope that woman has ſomething to confeſſe will hang 'em both.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sirha, you'll pull your deſtinie upon you
If you ceaſe not the ſooner.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: Nay, I have done, my Liege; yet it grieves me that I ſhould call that man Father, that ſhould be ſo ſhame|leſſe, that being commanded to hold his tongue.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To th' Porters Lodge with him.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: I thank your Grace, I have a friend there.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Speak woman, if any interruption meet thee more,
It ſhall be puniſh'd ſharply.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Good my Liege (I dare not)
Ask you the queſtion why that old man weeps.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who? Count Julio? I obſerv'd it not.
You hear the queſtion Sir, will you give the cauſe?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh my Lord, it hardly will get paſſage,
It is a ſorrow of that greatneſſe grown,
'Leſſe it diſſolve in tears, and come by parcels.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: I'll help you Sir, in the delivery,
And bring you forth a joy. You loſt a daughter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Twas that recounted thought brought forth theſe ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Shee's found again. Know you this mantle Sir?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Nay leave your wonder, I'll explain it to you.
This did enwrap your childe (whom ever ſince▪
I have call'd mine) when Nurſe Amaranta
In a remove from Mora to Corduba
Was ſeiz'd on by a fierce and hungry Bear,
She was the Ravins prey, as heaven ſo would,
He with his booty fill'd, forſook the babe:
All this was in my ſight: and ſo long I ſaw,
Untill the cruell creature left my ſight,
At which advantage I adventur'd me
To reſcue the ſweet Lamb: I did it Sir,
And ever ſince I have kept back your joy,
And made it mine: but age hath wearied me,
And bids me back reſtore unto the owner
What I unjuſtly kept theſe fourteen yeers.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, thou haſt ta'n ſo many yeers from mee,
And made me young, as was her birth-day to me.
Oh (good my Liege) give my joyes a pardon,
I muſt go powre a bleſſing on my child,
Which here would be too rude and troubleſome. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Franio, you knew this before.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Oh, oh; Item for you Miller.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I did (my Liege) I muſt confeſſe I did,
And I confeſſe, I ne'r would have confeſſ'd,
Had not that womans tongue begun to me:
We poor ones love, and would have comforts, Sir,
As well as great: this is no ſtrange fault, Sir,
There's many men keep other mens children
As though they were their own.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: It may ſtretch farther yet, I beſeech you (my Liege) let this woman be a little farther examin'd; let the words of her conſcience be ſearch'd. I would know how ſhe came by me: I am a loſt childe, if I be theirs: though I have been brought up in a mill, yet I had ever a minde (me thought) to be a greater man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Shee will reſolve you ſure.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: I, I Boy: thou art mine own fleſh and blood,
Born of mine own body.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: 'Tis very unlikely that ſuch a body ſhould bear me; There's no truſt in theſe millers. Woman, tell the truth: my father ſhall forgive thee, whatſoever he was, were hee Knight, Squire, or Captain; leſſe he ſhould not be.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Thou art mine own child, Boy.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: And was the Miller my Father?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Wouldſt thou make thy mother a whore, Knave?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.p: I, if ſhe make me a Baſtard. The rack muſt make her confeſſe (my Lord) I ſhall never come to know who I am elſe. I have a worſhipfull mind in mee ſure: mee thinks I do ſcorn poor folks.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here comes the brighteſt glory of the day:
Love yoak'd with love, the beſt equality,
Without the levell of eſtate or perſon.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You both ſhall be rewarded bountifully,
Wee'll be a-kin too; Brother and Siſter
ſhall be chang'd with us ever.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Thank you (Unkle) my ſiſter is my coſen yet at the laſt caſt: Farewell ſiſter foſter. If I had known the Civill law would have allowed it, thou hadſt had another manner of husband then thou haſt: but much good doe thee; I'll dance at thy wedding, kiſſe the Bride, and ſo.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why, how now ſirha?

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: 'Tis lawfull now, ſhe's none of my Siſter.
It was a Miller and a Lord
That had a ſcabberd and a ſword,
He put it up in the Country word
The Miller and his daughter.
Shee has a face, and ſhe can ſing,
Shee has a Grace, and ſhe can ſpring,
Shee has a place with another thing
Tradoodle.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A knaviſh Brother of yours (my Lord).

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: would I were acquainted with your Tailor (No|ble Brother).

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You may, there he is a mine, newly entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If you have any work for me, I can fit you Sir,
I fitted the Lady.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: My Siſter (Tailor,) what fits her wil hardly fit me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Who fits her may fit you Sir, the Tailor can do both.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: You have a true yard (Tailor.)

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ne'r a whit too long, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Buſt.
sp.l: Then (Tailor) march with me away,
I ſcorn theſe robes, I muſt be gay,
My Noble Brother, he ſhall pay
Tom Tailor. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your recovered friendſhips are ſound, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: At heart, at heart (my Lord) the worm ſhall not
Beyond many ages find a breach to enter at.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Theſe Lovers unities I will not doubt of:
How happy have you made our Progreſſe then,
To be the witneſſe of ſuch fair Accords?
Come, now we'll eat with you (my Lord Otrante,)
'Tis a charge ſav'd: You muſt not grudge your gueſt,
'Tis both my Welcome, and your Wedding-Feaſt.
